The Hunter: Call of the Wild is a hunting simulator that offers a realistic and immersive experience of tracking and hunting various wild animals in a vast open world. The game features two regions, Hirschfelden and Layton Lake, each with its own unique flora and fauna, weather, and terrain. Players can choose from a range of weapons, tools, and equipment to aid them in their hunts, as well as customize their character and lodge. The game also supports online multiplayer, allowing players to hunt cooperatively or competitively with up to seven other hunters.

The game's strongest aspect is its stunning graphics and sound design, which create a convincing and atmospheric representation of nature. The environments are richly detailed and dynamic, with changing seasons, time of day, and weather effects. The animals are also well-animated and behave realistically, reacting to the player's presence, scent, and noise. The sound effects of the game are equally impressive, with ambient noises of the forest, animal calls, and gunshots adding to the immersion. The game also features a relaxing and fitting soundtrack that complements the mood of the game.

However, the game is not without its flaws. The game's pace is very slow and requires a lot of patience and perseverance from the player. Tracking and hunting an animal can take a long time, and sometimes the player may end up empty-handed after hours of searching. The game also has a steep learning curve, with many aspects of the game being poorly explained or not explained at all. The game's user interface is also cluttered and confusing, making it hard to navigate and access the game's features. The game also suffers from some technical issues, such as bugs, glitches, and crashes, which can ruin the game's experience.

The Hunter: Call of the Wild is a game that will appeal to those who have a genuine passion for hunting, or those who enjoy nature simulation games. The game offers a realistic and challenging hunting experience, as well as a beautiful and relaxing exploration of the wilderness. However, the game is not for everyone, as it can be frustrating, boring, and inaccessible for those who are not used to the game's genre, mechanics, and pace. The game also needs some polishing and optimization to fix its technical problems. The game is a niche product, but a well-made one for its target audience.

It takes a while to get going on this game, but once you've managed to go up a few levels and get some skills under your belt, it's a really great game! HOWEVER, this game is not for the impatient types. This game requires infinite patience and stealth, but if you can do that, it's a very rewarding experience. Big hint, animals can hear you walking normally 200 meters away and will spook and run. You need to crouch and creep in when you're within 200 meters. Also, hunt around water sources. It took me a while to figure this out and I was frustrated that I wasn't seeing any animals. Once I started doing this though, I was able to drop animals consistently and leveled up pretty quickly.

This game is my first experience with a hunting simulator and has swiftly become one of my all-time favorites. The game demands patience, particularly in the early stages. I started in the expansive Layton Lake District reserve, where I continue to hunt and complete quests. My first successful hunt came after several hours of gameplay. Initially, I kept inadvertently scaring off animals without even seeing them. I then discovered that moose were the least timid creatures in the area. I set out to hunt a moose and managed to stealthily crawl within shooting range. However, due to either the insufficient power of my starter weapon or non-fatal shots, the animals would flee, wounded, and I couldn’t find them. My first successful harvest was a moose cow, which I stumbled upon accidentally and managed to take down with several point-blank shots from various weapons. She took me down in the process as well. 
With time and practice, I’ve honed my skills and can now harvest animals with relative ease. However, certain animals still demand patience, a skillful approach, and a well-placed shot to a vital organ. Additionally, some quests present quite a challenge, requiring not only patience but also a dash of creativity for successful completion.

Overall, I really like the game. Even after more than 200 hours of playing, there is still a huge amount of content left. I appreciate that this isn’t an arcade game, but rather a game that closely resembles real hunting (as much as a game can). That being said, there are deliberate assumptions in the game to simplify certain aspects. For instance, I don’t believe that in real life, wild animals would allow you to get as close to them as you can in the game, or that they wouldn’t notice your flashlight at night or your dog barking. However, I think the developers have managed to strike a balance, making the game appealing to both supporters of realism in simulation games and casual players who might be put off by excessive realism.

Many people complain that most of the content of the game is locked in the DLCs. The DLCs do bring a lot of additional content. However, the base game alone has enough content for hundreds of hours, and the DLCs are not expensive, especially when they are on sale. 
At present, the content offered by the two reserves in the base game sufficiently meets my needs. I have yet to explore the reserves introduced in the DLCs, as I intend to complete the quests in Layton Lake and Hirschfelden first.
Since the game has enough outposts for fast travel, it won’t take much time to get to any location on the map after you unlock the outposts (use the lookout towers to find them), and walking adds to realism. But if you’re not a fan of walking and want to make your life easier the ATV DLC and the Tents and Ground Blinds DLC should be the first ones to consider purchasing.

So, whether you’re an avid hunter, someone who has never hunted but wants to experience it, or simply a nature lover who doesn’t have the time or opportunity to venture outdoors, I recommend this game to you. By the way, the game’s depiction of nature is truly beautiful. 
I don’t hunt in real life because I can’t bear to kill animals. However, this game allows me, and many others with a deep-seated hunter’s instinct, to fully engage in the thrill of hunting and tracking prey without harming a single real animal.

I'm going to start this off saying this: 
I love this game, it is one of my favorite out of my entire steam library of 100+ games. 
The reason for not recommending it is that it still has major issues with DLCs and paid maps. I would much rather wait longer for a DLC then get a broken one. Two of my map story missions are broken and I cant continue them. When I buy a game I expect it to work. A few bugs here and there are fine and can be easily looked past. For example on the ATVs in the game if you get off it at the wrong time on a hill you can be launched across the map. While frustrating at times it is actually kinda funny. However I can not look past story missions being broken for this long. Once these bugs are fixed and I can continue the story mode I will write a better review.

BUT this game has some flaws. its a bit older now so I'm not going to rag on it too hard about controls. But this games item/weapon swap and selection is really slow and frustrating, also whoever came out with the cabin storage system just did not think it through. if I buy ammo for a gun, I shouldn't have to pull it out of storage then put in in my inventory then select which weapon I need it on. When there is only one weapon running that ammo type in my inventory!!! Also the company that made this game seems to be cash hungry. The things that didn't come with this game should seem really basic and is kind of ridiculous they would ask you to buy them. Such as hunting dogs, four wheeler, better weapons, and more maps. After 7 years, the game still receives quarterly updates with bug fixes and new DLC, offering a base game with two extensive maps and numerous missions, providing over 100 hours of gameplay. However, persistent major issues detract from the experience:

1. Animals exhibit erratic behavior, freezing or getting stuck in terrain.
2. Bullets are hindered by invincible terrain and oversized tree hitboxes.
3. Walking on various surfaces produces different noise levels, but unfortunately, the generated sound often mismatches the surface. For instance, walking on short green grass may occasionally produce louder noise than walking on surfaces with small stones and sticks. This is bad if we consider that sounds do scare animals.
4. Utilizing trees and bushes for cover is inconsistently effective. Occasionally, a small bush can offer complete concealment, while a large tree fails to hide the hunter. It has always been like that, worsening notably after a specific update over two years ago. Unfortunately, the map that is affected the most appears to be Hirschfelden, which is one of the two maps in the base game. Despite developer awareness, there has been no public acknowledgment. 
5. The draw distance is limited, causing distant objects to appear pixelated or not rendered, even with maxed-out graphics settings. This significantly hampers immersion, especially when you are looking thru scopes or binoculars.
6. Sound levels remain unbalanced, a persistent issue where some sounds are excessively loud while others are too low. Despite multiple attempts by the developers to adjust them, progress has been minimal.
7. Getting stuck in missions is a frequent issue, and while updates occasionally resolve the problem, it's also common to face permanent obstructions. This leaves many players with no recourse but to start anew, resulting in the loss of hundreds of hours, although trophies in lodges are retained.
8. Foliage sounds, triggered when the player interacts with bushes or trees, frequently become persistent and replay even when the player is no longer in contact. This persistent and annoying bug appears to be unfixable, causing consistent frustration. And guess what, these sounds also do scare animals.
9. Save file wipes are not uncommon, occurring either due to bugs, cloud issues, mods, or prolonged absence from the game.
10. Certain sounds are consistently misdirected, a problem that started since an update 1.5 year ago, and a fix is still pending.
11. Volumetric fog causes strange lighting artifacts and pixelation when this setting is turned on, especially when there's a lot of fog against a bright background. They broke this setting by accident during a hotfix 1.5 year ago and despite numerous notices from the community, they haven't bother to fix it. They even claimed that they fixed it (twice). This setting is a must if you truly want to experience the game's atmosphere.
12. Multiplayer experience is much worse than single player. Often too buggy to be enjoyable. It has been said by EW multiple times that they haven't designed the game with multiplayer in mind. So be prepared for major issues if you are planning to play with friends, and make sure you've searched the forums before buying.

While the base game's maps are visually appealing, subsequent maps often seem low-effort, with less engaging missions. Buy the base game first and consider DLCs later, as the game's size remains the same for all players. Multiplayer allows access to DLC maps even without ownership.

The target audience is those who enjoy casual, patient hunting in a slow-paced, stealth-oriented game. For me it is more of a walking simulator with occasional hunting due to the numerous mechanics issues.

Lastly, the game description on the store page claims "regularly updated in collaboration with the community." Don't make the mistake to think that this is about mods. There's no support for modding, and it's even worse, mods are forbidden. There's zero collaboration with the community whatsoever.

TLDR: If you are looking for a serious hunting game, you'll probably be disappointed. The base game is acceptable though if you keep your expectations low. The graphics up close look great; it's an immersive experience, and can serve very well as a walking sim too, especially Hirschfelden which is one of the maps in the base game. Most practical DLCs: ATV, bloodhound, and tents.

i used to play theHunter: Classic on my very shitty HP laptop that acts as if it's the only generator powering an entire airport. but after getting a new laptop and are now finally able to play COTW instead, i can safely say that this is a very fun game.

each map is so unique and i love how free roam it can get, and also that it doesn't bind me to missions and i can turn them off or on depending on my mood. i've never hunted before IRL but it feels pretty realistic- until i'm shooting at a very specific bison like... 7 times and it gets bugged in game and stands still and when it finally drops it's still alive... i couldn't harvest the kill that day. 

OR when i spotted a herd of caribou in Yukon Valley; only intended to shoot a bull bc of the rack and when i did, the whole herd literally stood in game, bugged, couldn't move, so i just took 'em all out. my Bloodhound had a easily good time that's for sure. 

yes, i've dealt my fair share of bugs in this game, but it's not too bad, just not ideal when playing multiplayer w/ friends but even then we still find a way to enjoy our time. 

my only biggest concerns really revolve around the DLCs; while i'm very glad that i got the Master Hunter Bundle when it was on sale during December, i still found it very confusing that if i hadn't, i would need the DLC to even get the 4x4s.... i agree with other players that say the vehicles should just be apart of the base game. 

TL;DR: good game, should get for fun if you've never hunted IRL but like hunting sims, DLCs can be pretty arguable. breathtaking maps IMO, i even hallucinate seeing the in-game lit up animal tracks IRL when walking sometimes.

A really excellent game. Even if you've never played a hunting game before, this one will lure you in and make you love the genre. The hunting is the best of its generation of games, yet to be surpassed by newcomers. It has good gunplay and ballistics, excellent missions and storylines, and [i]bespoke[/i] maps, each 64sqkm in size and with their own draws and atmosphere. The range of huntable animals is wonderful if you're a completionist or a collector, and you can hang them in your trophy lodge. Whether you want to hop on to kill a few while you kill time, want to complete all the missions or collect one diamond of each species, or simply want to explore the maps: this game has something for everyone.

A veteran player's review: 8k+ hours on console and pc: If you enjoy exploring, collecting trophies, beautiful scenery, and an amazing community then this game is for you. CoTW The Hunter is a great game to play if you are unable to experience hunting IRL or if your dream is to hunt other parts of the world. There is a large variety of maps with animals that you can hunt, collect, and display in a lodge. It's a great game for both avid and new hunters. The lodges allow you to track your progression over the months or even years which is great if you are a trophy collector/grinder. You can easily get distracted while exploring the beautiful maps. Even after playing the game for years I still find myself always coming back to explore where I left off or trying out the the new content. Keep in mind all games have bugs so I would be lying if I said the game didn't have any. But EW is on point when it comes to fixes. This is a great experience if playing with your friends or family. The best part about the game is the community. -Happy Hunting

The game is slow paced and can be boring when you are lure hunting and staking out a need zone or similar.
BUT
Here's the thing...
That IS hunting. It takes patience and while there are some QoL stuff behind DLC paywalls... [spoiler] [i]cough[/i] tents, treestands, blinds. [i]cough[/i] [/spoiler]
The game is well worth playing even WITHOUT them. The stalking and tracking is almost meditative for me and is almost half the point of the game. The game is SLOW PACED, but there is a depth in scouting the area and doing the prep work to find the best place to wait.

I have run into a time where I couldn't sleep [spoiler] in a tent which I got as part of a bundle [/spoiler] as I ran out of money and had to do some tricky night hunting to earn enough to get to the right time to hunt what I was after.

THAT SAID:
SPENDING that time doing prep and hunting lesser game to solve the problem was rewarding and let me practice and made me feel like the [strike]hunter[/strike] Ranger or game warden that the game seems to be built around.

And that is another point. The game feels [b]LESS[/b] like a hunting sim and [b][i]MORE[/i][/b] like a park ranger and game warden sim at times.
[b]BUT THAT ISN'T A BAD THING[/b]
The game focuses quite a lot on 'Hunting as conservation' and 'ethical culls with minimal suffering' rather than the 'Only for a Trophy and toss the rest' style that some in the US might be familiar with.

I know where I live, hunting and fishing licences pay for most of the conservation and awareness stuff in the area and help KEEP the wilds..... well.... WILD

It is refreshing to see that reflected in game with the sort of hunts and missions offered:
Population control and culling species that are impacting the area negatively due to rising numbers.
Hunting invasive species.
Getting PHOTOS of wildlife for awareness pieces and articles.
Etc.

It is a slow game.
If you are looking for a TROPHY hunter with tag and bag mechanics..... perhaps look elsewhere.
BUT
If you want a hunting game where you can feel the full reward of slowly stalking and tracking game across the landscape or setting up and sitting in ambush in a routinely traveled route you identified through study...
THEN this game will probably be up your alley.

I really loved this game for a while, but the sad truth is, it's just not a good game. The gameplay is too repetitive, the animal behavior is way off. there are SO many bugs. Half of the maps are awful, half the guns are terrible and no one uses them anymore because the devs just add better versions of them (M1 Garand and Zarza .308). There is so much potential to this game but the other main problem is the Great One grinding. Great Ones are destroying the game, there's too much focus on teleporting around to lakes, shooting animals and resetting the clock in the hopes you get a GO to spawn in. Things NEED to be more random, the truracks don't do much since no one cares about getting weirdly shaped antlers, plus even if someone did, the devs still haven't put nontypical racks in. I'm still going to buy every DLC they come out with in the hopes they can fix the game for me, but I don't see it getting any better.

[h2]Nice visuals and exploration experience, but the weapons feel unsatisfying to use. [/h2]

Note: Got this on sale. Initial experience included buying the QoL DLC, namely the tents and the ATV ones, so the distance and "saving" weren't a problem. They really should be included in the base game, though, as others have said. tl;dr at the end.

[i]Disclaimer: [/i] I don't play games much, but I played Insurgency (2014) a lot before, and it had really satisfying and responsive weapons, so I'm mainly comparing theHunter:COTW to that game.

My main problem with the game is with the handling of the weapons, which is the focus of this review. 
The gun handling in the game JUST doesn't feel right or good. 

For example, on reloading. Using the revolvers, why does he reload so slowly? And of course, something like "reloading while running" is locked as a "perk". I wonder how many more perks are needed to get the character to a not-annoying level?

Moving on, the lever action shotgun has a similar painstakingly-slow reload sequence. Reloading the AR-style rifles also has this part where he seems to miss the mag well [b]every time[/b] as he casually brings up a fresh mag at a glacial pace? Gets old fast.

Reload cancelling should be part of the game as well. Sometimes, you just need 2 shots on the revolver, so Lclick should make him stop reloading and get ready to fire. It's so annoying to wait for the whole reload sequence when "reloading to full" isn't the only realistic way to reload, if realism is one of the game's goals.

Overall, the reloading animations seem so artificially slowed down, with the .357 revolver reload for example, looking stiff and robotic, and not in a good way.

The round count per magazine is cursed as well. Based on my research, some hunting places do have regulations on magazine capacity. (The one I saw was 5 rounds for semi auto.)

And, for games, I'm not for 45-round extended magazines in a slow-paced hunting experience, but the M1 Garand style rifle has the en bloc clip with just 5 rounds. They couldn't even make it an even number and pretend that in the game universe, their M1 Garands had 6 rounds per clip. 

And the AR-15 and AR-10 as well with the 5-round magazines. It seems like the hunter is nerfing his own hunting experience by not getting normal mags. Or are those locked behind a perk system as well? 
Maybe the reserve rules on round count can be different per reserve, so there's more variety: one reserve can have 10 rounds, another can have 5, etc.

On the topic of aiming, the ADS scope wobble is insanely nasty as well. It looks like the player is drunk holding the gun. It even happens when in the prone position. Is there no way to set the rifle on your bag or a rock or something so it's more stable? That, or have a bipod attachment. Seems like a basic "realistic" thing to add [strike]as DLC or something[/strike] to the base game.

Adding to that, the guy's aim gets all wobbly and tired (Elevated heart rate! Oh my!) after like 2-3 shots when ADSing. It does not seem realistic that the guy can hike miles and miles up and down mountains like in "Lone Survivor" carrying like 3 guns plus other gear no problem, but he can't shoot well after 2-3 shots. 

Other suggestions: 
[list]
[*] Don't wait for the newly-selected item/weapon to fully come up if you select another item.
[*] Have an option at the shooting range to retain infinite ammo, but have the round count per gun be respected, so reloads can be timed and included when practicing. 
[*] Better photography mode with changeable lenses, depth of field, focus distance, aperture, etc.
[*] Hotkey to remove all the added things on screen for better screenshots without having to wait to pull out the camera.
[*] Support for multiple save files
[*] Higher animal render distance
[*] More granular sound controls, like being able to turn the bike noise, wind, etc. down.
[/list]

tl;dr Overall, after hunting and tracking the animal, getting to the shooting part is just so unsatisfying and kills the joy out of the game for me because of the underwhelming weapon handling. I really want to recommend this game otherwise, because of the scenery and soundscape, but the weapons could use some work. At least the guns sound good.

I hope to revisit this title if they keep on updating it, as I haven't tried bows yet.

The maps are well made (for the most part) very big, not to mention quite a few of them (and props to host sharing DLC maps if the other players don't have them). The graphics are decent and you can really 'polish' them off with Reshade.
It's not a realistic game to the max, animals aren't spooked by light, sight mechanics are basic, tracks are fairly easy to follow with the bright overlay (though I'd prefer Classic huntermate system), but the game doesn't offer much beyond hunting the rares and doing SP missions. It does offer a way to burn some time and can be fun with friends.
Multiplayer co-op is basic, some actual co-op style random missions/events wouldn't go amiss here (and in SP).
It feels like something is missing from the game, there's no skinning etc, random events, those ATV's are horrible (parachutes, gliders for funsies? Better vehicles? Horses?), some flavour on the side between hunts?

A few glitches and bugs... Audio on the wrong side of your player to the call, animal rustling when there is no animals around, certain maps do not AI well, the Cuatro Colinas for example; In several sessions and 90% of the time the AI will freeze on the spot, run as if stuck in the ground and just otherwise just derp out... Having tracked down mythical+'s in this only to see them not respond at all and bleed out on the spot whilst you stand next to them is very disappointing.
Sometimes tracks disappear entirely, whilst I would expect an element of randomness with tracks, a vital-organ hit with a medium bleed not producing a single blood patch over 200 meters with no corpse in sight and the dog just as confused as you are, or the tracks missing entirely is a problem, especially since most animals don't bolt in one direction and keep going, running circles around the area making it impossible to find anything.
The Hunt Club BETA is dodgy... Still.
And at the end of the day when you're done with the game, hard reboot the PC because it's got some kind of memory access issue and locks up the system after long sessions, or even blue screens it (on multiple systems).

More fixes, more content please...

theHunter: Call of the Wild is the worst kind of game, because it "hits the dopamine receptors" but ends up being just a bad-but-compelling time sink.

The best part of it is that it showcases incredible hunting areas that one can actually visit in real life.

The worst part is that the gun-handling feels as if all hunting rifles weighed 30 lbs and have no bipods, and you have to buy ATV DLC to get anywhere in-game in a reasonable amount of time. It feels like the devs don't care about the core game loop and only focus on DLC.

Further, the animal AI and hit registration is terrible. I pumped moose full of .270, and it ran in circles caught on terrain. I pumped another moose full of .357 magnum with no reaction whatsoever. If you shoot a deer in the head (which is reasonable if you have a tree stand and just want meat) then the deer isn't guaranteed to die.

Especially menus aren't very well made, for instance if you play on a high dpi mouse and want to reduce your sensitivity, you have to click 50 times on a down arrow to move sensitivity from 100% to 50%. Worst UI ever.

I have definitely loved this game since the first time I played it on my xbox ages ago. Although I have been playing it for years, just the opportunity of what special types of animals you can hunt always keeps me coming back for more. I love how well the  game works. Although I have also experienced my share of glitches and mishaps; from losing a full save of all my kills and money (did not lose my real money purchased add ons), to having 6 large deer herds spawn in a feed or drink zone at one time and they all glitch still and don't run when I walk up and shoot them in the face. 

I would still recommend this game to any and all my friends, I love to play it. It is relaxing yet so exhilarating. And it definitely scratches my itch when I miss hunting season in the real world.

When I purchased this game I set out a little challenge for myself to try and gauge if this was a good buy, although I had purchased some map DLC's during a Christmas sale I vowed not to go to them until I finished the base maps that you get when you purchase this game standalone, along with filling the one free hunting lodge you receive. I fully expected to get bored and uninstall before I reached my goal.

This game pleasantly surprised me, granted this game is not for everyone but when you buy a hunting simulation you know what you're getting into.

The base game consists of 2 maps of a couple kilometers/miles in diameter that you can explore seamlessly without any loading beyond the initial booting up of the game. One set in Germany, and the other set in America, Each with 8 different animals with which to hunt, totalling 16. Initially it might not sound like a lot of animals but the game hooks you in with a trophy score system, of which you're chasing forever more incrementally higher trophy scores, each of which is separated into 4 tiers, bronze, silver, gold and diamond along with a worse than bronze tier which doesn't award anything and a special "Great One" tier above diamond which is for special spawns that have a unique skin.

Each map has a story associated with it, of which you'll be Hunting Z number of Y in X area with W weapon, though it spices things up by making you take pictures occasionally, tracking foot/pawprints (some of which belong to people), one quest that lets you choose to either take a photograph or put down a creature at the behest of two competing rivals (you can choose both without penalty or needing to time travel) and you even put out a fire at one point. 

The story is dictated to you by a single entity who acts as a sort of manager who interacts with your employers on your behalf, forwarding requests and payment upon completion, all the while dictating whats going on in these peoples lives as it happens, you never actually meet another human unless you join a multiplayer game.

I would say I'm a pretty average player when it comes to this game, but in order to complete both maps story mode (Of which I completed my collection of Gold or better trophy's on the way through) it took me 132 hours, I'd say that's pretty good value for money considering I only paid 5 dollars for it, 20 if you count every DLC I purchased.

You'll hear a lot of complaints about the nickle and diming the game does with its DLC, and I partially agree on the topics of the vehicle (Of which not getting it has no downfall beyond unlocking initial survey points thanks to the fast travel system) and the dogs (Which is actually a quality of life improvement when it comes to tracking bleeding marks, or not having to move from your hunting blind to capture ducks and geese, something i think should be in the base game).

Honestly you could buy the base game and have a decently good time without purchasing any DLC, but I have anyway and am looking forward to exploring Africa and Australia with my dog and my ATV.

On a footnote I feel like the game doesn't have much to spend your in game currency on, yet paradoxically I still seem to constantly be running out. Setting up your lodge just the way you like is very satisfying.

[h1] The Ultimate Hunting Experience [/h1]
Experience an atmospheric hunting game like no other in this realistic and visually breathtaking open world. Immerse yourself in the atmospheric single player campaign, or share the ultimate hunting experience with friends. With many animals and locations, it is now time to finally enjoy a hunting game with friends in an experience not many games can create. Get ready for the ultimate hunting season and enjoy the thrill of the hunt!

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]About[/th]
        [th]Description[/th]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]💾Graphics[/td]
        [td]If you are a huge lover of gorgeous environments that feel truly immersive and filled with life, this game is top tier. The lush foliage with the trees moving against the wind looks so stunning. After all of the time I play this game I still get a feeling of awe when I load this game up. The lighting is superb especially at night, and the textures are still really impressive with the fur, and foliage looking really impressive. This game still holds up so well in terms of graphics. Absolutely stunning that will still hold up well in years to come.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎮Gameplay[/td]
        [td]I never played a hunting game before in my life and never thought I would be into it, but this game changed my opinion. The feel of the hunt and stalking your prey feels so rewarding. Also some animals can get hostile towards you which is really cool to see. The weapons pack a punch and feel unique from each other. Many different kinds of species to hunt and every animal you do hunt has a trophy rating ranging from bronze, silver, gold, and diamond. You can collect the animal you hunted and show it off at your lodge. Many animals have different furs, adding to the rarity of them. The maps are really massive, promoting long distance sniping even which feels extremely rewarding. You can even check what part of the body you hit your target. Depending on where you hit the animal, they can bleed out really fast, adding to the score of the animal you've been stalking. The game is slow paced so if you are looking for a fast pace hunting game, this is not it. This game rewards patience and good shooting. You do have a perk system that can make it easier to stalk your prey, but be aware that you may find it difficult to track your hunt. Just be patient and don’t get distracted and you will find what you are looking for. Stealth and noise is super important as well, because if you move to a bush too fast you can alert the animal. Be slow, and quiet and you will be successful at your hunts. My biggest complaint in this game is the DLC’s. Most of the good stuff is locked behind a paywall. For example ATV, tents, treestand, tripods, lodges, camo’s, maps, and of course weapons. Luckily the maps can be played if you have a friend that has the DLC maps so you don’t really need them, but if you plan on playing single player then of course you need them. Besides that the gameplay mechanics are really well done and enjoy them a ton![/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]📜Story[/td]
        [td]Every map has its own story. Some are better than others but I never really cared too much about them. Luckily some of the stories reward you with some great hunts and weapons. Don’t expect amazing story telling or an in depth lore with these maps. The stories do a fine job, but I tend to get more distracted by hunting to to be honest.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎭Multiplayer[/td]
        [td]Multiplayer is really well implemented into this game. First of all if your friend has a DLC map and you don’t, they can host it and still invite you to join. Hunting with a friend was absolutely amazing and I highly recommend this experience if you plan on getting this game. It’s super immersive and addicting. One complaint is that you should not invite random people. Let's say you take down a diamond animal, the other player can just go to the animal and take it from you. Now you still get the money, but you can’t harvest it and save it to show off to your lodge. You can get random trolls so just play with friends only.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🕛Playtime[/td]
        [td]You can add many hours into this game, especially if you own some DLC maps. The game can get stale on the base game since the maps are kinda meh. I have up to 155+ hours and have tons to do like hunt gold and diamond animals, get animals with rare furs, explore the maps more, etc. This game has a huge replay value to it and if you are a fan of hunting, you may add hundreds of hours easily.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🎧Sound[/td]
        [td]The sound design is top tier hands down! The animals make their realistic mating, and hunting calls. Every animal sounds true to their real life counterpart. The weapons sound so incredible too. So loud and punchy! Shooting guns in this game feels so satisfying to me. The music is also pretty fitting for this game, although I just turn it off to get more immersed into the world and environments.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❗Bugs❗[/td]
        [td]I haven’t really had any issues with bugs. Placing tents can be kinda finicky and annoying at times but besides that nothing bad. The game feels pretty polished for the most part. I’m sure there are bugs in this game depending on the map, so do keep that in mind. I just didn’t really have anything jump at me that I saw worth mentioning.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔅Performance[/td]
        [td]The performance is really good! Playing on near ultra settings, I never really had frame drops. A smooth solid 60 fps on my rig and I was actually surprised by that. The game is well optimized. Also I never had a crash or annoying stutters.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]✔️Pro’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Stunning graphics
[*]Animal trophy system
[*]Beautiful environments
[*]Realistic animal callings
[*]Incredible sound design
[*]Co-op is well implemented
[*]Many types of animals to hunt
[*]Challenging/Immersive experience
[*]Scent and wind direction mechanics
[*]Lodge to show off your hunted animals
[*]Stealth and noise plays an important role
[*]Shot placement on animals is very important
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]❌Con’s[/td]
        [td][list]
[*]Night Vision is useless (DLC)
[*]Only three magnifications on scopes
[*]Inventory system could use some work
[*]Many DLC's should have been in the base game
[/list]
[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🏆Rating[/td]
        [td]8.5/10
Base game is worth the full price. If you plan on buying a bundle, get the “Season Hunter Bundle” or “Master Hunter Bundle” on sale.[/td]
    [/tr]
    [tr]
        [td]🔗Conclusion[/td]
        [td]For my first ever hunting game, I’m really impressed and it left a great first impression on me. The hunting felt so immersive and addicting and I was so shocked I was really into it. As a non hunter in irl, I can’t tell you how realistic it is but it felt pretty convincing. If you are looking to get into a hunting game especially with friends, I really recommend this game.If you can save some extra money you should get the “Season Hunter Bundle” or “Master Hunter Bundle” as that has many good essential DLC in my opinion to make your experience even greater.
[/td]
    [/tr]
[/table]

I bought call of the wild over a year ago. I have around 920 hours into this game (as of this 1st review). Overall I like the game and it does not feel like a grind trying to level up. It only feels like a grind if you are purposely trying to go after diamond animals. This game was very stable until many months ago when they introduced the bloodhound DLC. If you bought this DLC and installed it then you were introduced to many critical bugs in the game. A patch was released for this DLC which fixed some of the bugs but introduced more bugs.

Then when they introduced the Rancho De Arrroy map DLC, it injected even more critical bugs and even some game breaking bugs. I will not get into all the bugs here there are way too many. If you want to know more just go to the steam forums and read the bug reports and you will see them all listed there. Many people have gotten increasingly frustrated with the direction this game has taken. What was once a stable game has now become a bug infested mess. 

I hardly play this game anymore because of all the bugs. Some people have reported a lot of crashes going on, some people have lots of lost frame rates, audio issues, missing tracks, unable to fast travel from outpost to outpost. It is a real mess. EW released a patch in July/August to address these critical bugs. For some people it fixed some of them. But there still is a great number of people who are still encountering the same bugs.

Would I recommend this game?

As far as its potential, its game playing when there are no major bugs present I would recommend this game... BUT ONLY... If this games bugs were fixed. There are still some bugs that are there from the very start I bought it. Some of these bugs are important to me like missing tracks or tracks that are pointed in the wrong direction. It is still not fixed. I understand that each game has some bugs, but they are typically just minor bugs that do not affect the game stability and game play. But when a game becomes this bug infested and the enjoyment of the game is lost it's time to put the game aside and find something else.

I used to be a programmer and I can confidently say that all the bugs that are being reported and that I have run into are not hardware-based, but code based. That tells me that EW has either lost interest in fixing this game or they do not have programmers who are qualified to work on this game.

So I would not recommend this game if you do not like bugs in your game.

UPDATE 12/11/2021
After the release of the Mississippi DLC update. Things HAVE NOT gotten any better. There are still lots of previous bugs that are still not fixed. a few that were fixed back in AUG is broke again. It just doesn't end. This game is getting worst

UPDATE (11-18-2022)
I encounter my last game-breaking bug. I went to travel from Silver Peaks map to Rancho map (using H shortcut key). The game crashed. After rebooting and relaunching the game. It never worked again.

I DO NOT recommend this game at all with all these bugs

UPDATE (2/1/2024)
I played the game again since being off of it for 1 year. There are still bugs. The one glaring one is... after laying down bird decoys and then trying dismantle them (X button) it would remove the decoy, then it would put you in Photo mode. Then after pressing/holding X button it would deploy my Tent. After cancelling tent, I then had to move my camera up/down to get the "dismantle" X icon to appear so I could remove the next decoy. Rinse-and-repeat for the decoys. So frustrating.

Because of the bugs and other reasons, I no longer use the weapons for hunting. Basically I just use this game as a photography game where I just walk around and photograph each animal on each reserve. Its is challenging still to be able to get as close as you can. Other than that, I feel the game has not improved bug wise.

The Hunter: Call of the Wild is a game that transcends the hunting genre, providing an immersive wilderness experience that can make you happily lost in its beauty and depth. The realism, attention to detail, and absence of hand-holding elements contribute to an experience that captures the essence of nature. If you're seeking a gaming adventure where getting lost is not a flaw but a feature, The Hunter: Call of the Wild is a captivating odyssey into the heart of the untamed.

This game is amazing! Dive into stunning landscapes, hunt realistically behaving animals, and enjoy the immersive experience. The game's visuals, sound, and equipment variety make it a top-notch hunting simulation. For beginners, I recommend watching a video for tips on understanding animal behavior. It enhances your experience by helping you track and find them more easily. Personally, I'm addicted to buying DLCs; the additional content adds even more depth to the game and keeps my interest soaring. Plus, the multiplayer side allows me to enjoy challenges with friends, making it an even more exciting experience. A must-play for nature lovers and gamers – it's truly wild!

Got the game on a good sale for very cheap and am hooked. I'm considering picking up a few more havens to hunt in. The graphics are gorgeous and the gameplay loop is addicting. My only complaint is that getting new guns and the general level progression feels very slow, or maybe I'm not bad at this? I've never hunt in real life, but I love the outdoors and this hits the spot during the dead of winter. Overall this game is great, and an especially good deal on sale. Yeah there are micro-transactions, but the base game can be very heap and the DLC content appears worth it. Stuff like an ATV shouldn't be DLC, in my opinion, but you [i[can[i] fast-travel so it's not required, but I do strongly recommend it otherwise the game is pretty sloggish. The base game comes with two massive havens to hunt in, one of which is stunningly gorgeous and has a lot of things to hunt and do. For $10-$15 this game is very worth it, especially since the base game comes with two whole DLC level havens to hunt. If you consider it a $60 full price game, but sold at $10 and the rest of that $50 comes from what you want to buy via DLC.

Updated Review:
After reaching out to tech support and receiving a quick response, my issue was resolved, turned out to be corrupt update files.

If the game crashes for you, try this:
-Right-click the game name in your Steam library
-Click Properties
-Click Installed Files
-Click "Verify integrity of game cache"

If it tells you that files are corrupted, you can go to your downloads and move the game up in priority so they can updated immediately or wait for Steam to schedule and update them (which could take days).

Here is a link with additional troubleshooting steps they provided me with in case your issue isn't the same as mine: https://support.thehunter.com/hc/en-us/articles/4415698207890-I-can-t-launch-theHunter-Call-of-the-Wild-PC-

I'm changing my review to positive based on the great tech support provided, the game actually running and the initial screens and music being fantastic. I will update the review further once I actually get a chance to play the game.

Original Review:
Here is my experience with this game:
-Load Game
-See pretty background picture and hear beautiful music
-Click to skip account login
-Acknowledge that I can create an account at any time
-Watch game crash and want to send crash report

So for now I'll have to make this a negative review. Hopefully they will fix whatever the issue is so I can actually play the game and update my review down the road (hopefully to a positive one).

This game is ruined by the dirty feeling of being a scam/grift. This game takes walking simulator to a whole new level. The travel distances are huge, sometimes a mission is 40 minutes from your starting point, and if you close the game and come back later, you are right back were you started. It's understandable that it takes so long to WALK, after all it's a hunting game, so the maps are huge, which is why it's standard to have transportation in hunter games, with the tried and true, in every other hunting game being an atv, and sure enough, this game has an atv right in the cover photo! so there must be an ATV right? Well only if you pay the 4 dollar DLC. Classic bait and switch. If you're a gamer you know it's pretty standard for a game to be able to save your position, well not this game, nope it's DLC. The Tent DLC lets you save your progress, how incredible! To make matters worse the game crashes, so you'll really need those transportation dlcs.

First and most important: I recommend educating yourself thouroughly before you buy this game.
Now my experience and thoughts:
I really wanted to like this game and enjoy it to the fullest, however... 
As you could guess, it's a hunting simulator. Relatively realistic actually, but after doing some research, base game maps are considered the worst. Sure, you can play MP with a player who has a DLC with specific map, but when streamers and youtubers even encourage you to buy DLCs, that should speak VOLUMES. Beginings are always tough in every game, but here, you really are at a huge disadvantage, as perks and skills for sneakiness and stealth are higher up. So, it will be a huge grind until you can even possibly be a proper hunter. Also, if your computer is mediocre, excpect it to sound like a washing machine. I really should have refunded it while I could, but it was my Bday so I was like ''why not try something new?''

I will give props to graphics, as they are stunning, and the map is huge, which is both + and - : reasons being missions (won't spoil it but traversing really long distances and a basically waiting game for dozens of minutes at times for anything just to pass by) and also being relatevly slow in speed, both walking and running. It also makes it repetitive exploring new areas and having such big maps may be one of the reasons why my PC hates it when I play it. Again, you are almost obliged to buy DLCs, vehicle one especially. If you have lots of time or you enjoy the scenery, then this isn't as bad for you then. Also, regarding the maps, water areas are, compared to DLC maps, in most cases, very horrible for spotting and tracking. Highly recomend checking for yourself and if you do decide to buy DLC, be sure which one you get. 

As for gameplay, as I said, relatively realistic. It is good, as is the story and voice acting. My issue here may be that certain animals are almost unaproachable (this is where perks and skills at higher levels come at play, you really need them, but first ones aren't that good in my oppinion - look up a guide), or are scared for no reason. It also doesn't help the way animals move. Easily spooked even though they shouldn't be (there is a difference between rarer ones, as they spot you faster, but I doubt every fox and boar was a rare :D ) from distances greater than 100m-150m, even on low visibility and crouching. On the other hand, I got running like a maniac in certain parts and when I get into clearing, I spot a deer just a few dozen meters away, and sometimes it is rarer one. Inconsistent in my opinion.

Another very important thing - trophies. Yes, they exist, however, in base game (or was it free DLC, can't remember) you get a lodge, but you can only put 1 of EACH animal species in base game. So, if you caught cool Diamond ranked trophy of idk Roe Deer, and you have Albino Roe Deer, you can only put up one. You need one of 2 SEPARATE DLCs for the lodges that allows you to put around 200 (I think, definetly more than 100) trophies in total. 

Also, if I recall corectly, in one of the videos of youtuber LadyLegendXO, base maps earlier had more spawns/animals. It seems they reduced it (purposfully?), while DLC weapons and animals are both in abundance and better.

Just to be fair, my bad experience (apart from fear of computer exploding ofc) may be because this game genre may not be my cup of tea, or I just couldn't figure it out. Then again, there are lists on youtube with titles ''best starting maps for begginers'' and base game maps are always put last/worst, so take that into consideration. It's definetly not a game that is unplayable, but you do need a lot of time and grind. Also, it kind of breaks the immersion and/or is pointless to people who like singleplayer experience if you need to constantly go into other people's worlds.

TLDR; [b]buy on discount[/b], if you like the game, then get the ATV DLC. Or, buy the bundle from the start.

[h1]More Rants:[/h1]
At first impression, I dislike the extra maps to be in paid DLC, but, its reasonable, same for the cosmetics and dog companion. Then, I realized [b]there's FREE DLCs[/b], so I'm very impressed that the game is evolving through time based on real world.

Also, I do enjoy the game with realism on the hunting experience, learning to be patient before I pull the trigger and so on. Then I realized, hunting is a very expensive hobby, as you need to spend money to buy better gears, and player need to buy DLC for weapon packs to get better gears, just like in real world, LOL.

Joke aside, its a very nasty DLC, because the ATV is the only vehicle in game and this has been complained since 2017 by many players from day one. I know its not going to change soon, so I'm going to suggest this to the devs: please add one more FREE DLC to unlock a lower tier vehicle and balance it so that player need to reach certain in-game level to buy it. (or make it an exclusive event, idk)

About non-dlc weapon, the default rifle and free ammo is good to go. Most rifles are decent, yet, the meta is quite obvious, so player eventually go for the same choices. However, the handguns, shotguns and bows are mediocre.

Handguns: I was given a free Sundberg 454 and I wanted its "Tru-Vision Tritium Sights" but need a very high handgun score (too grindy), which I think is badly balanced.

Shotguns: very limited, and suffers from the same needed score issue.

Bows: needed a perk called "Recycle" to retrieve fired arrow, which I think is another bad balance to put it too far late at 3rd tier, should be 1st or 2nd tier on the perk's skill tree.

Also, the skill and perk points are gruesomely slow to grind, PLUS, the reset cost is TOO MUCH, if a beginner is testing out skill or perk, such penalty is too much, should use a cooldown timer instead of in-game money.

Also, the "Hardened" skill should also slowly regenerate health over time.

Finally, some tech issues for the devs:
- Borderless Window should be in-game option, player should not need to configure "/borderless" in launch option.
- should have a button to toggle on/off HUD icons, like hide animal clues.
- when auto-walk is on, interact should stop auto-walk (like harvest, access cache, etc)

The biggest Issue with this game is that progression is painfully, absurdly slow. It takes a ridiculous amount of time to acquire enough exp to unlock weapons/sights/calls what have you and then it takes an even longer amount of time to be able to afford to buy them. At 89 hours play time there is still so much I haven't unlocked it makes no sense. The second issue is that there are so many things that should be in the base game and have been in the base game of any other hunting game that I've played that are only in DLCs. Even after buying some of the DLCs  I am still missing so much basic content. In terms of the hunting aspect itself it's pretty good, but I would say much too unforgiving in the areas with dense vegitation where you can't see far. Overall, it's not bad but the progression issues and locking so much basic content behind DLCs really hold it back.

This is the best Hunting Simulator I've ever played.

I've gamed for over 40 years, played a ton of simulator games for most of those years, and this is the closest I've felt in a game to being in the woods actually hunting.  I grew up in the country and spent a good amount of time hunting with friends and family and this game gives you that feeling; the sounds, the calls of the animals, the echo effects and has absolutely beautiful maps and environments.  Even simulates some great details of shooting, like the scopes, the breathing, the feel of using bows and crossbows... little details.  

This game is excellent simulation of the real thing but still a really fun game to play.  And the DLCs are not needed to make it playable by itself but they are really well done too and add really good content.  I own them all and I'm really happy with all of them.  Such a chill escape to relax in and enjoy.  Love it.

Fun hunting game and I Love playing it. My main complaint is that some of the ballistic performance choices are kind of questionable when compared to reality. For example: the bullet's TOF and drop seem to be over exaggerated, and bullet penetration(performance) seems to be way lower than it actually would be, even when using the different ammo types. My last gripe is that you cannot make the animals render in at further distances, your limited to about a 450 yard radius. The only way to shoot further than 450 is to have the animal 450yds away and you be on some type of elevation or vice versa. I do really love this game it looks and runs great; even the complaints I have aren't game breaking for me, they can just be annoying sometimes when certain situations come up.

(Quick Note on Review Edit: If you find your character to be slow at running and reloading, turn off Antiostropic Filtering. After that, turn off Global Illumination if you still need speed without sacrificing the other options. I have maximum settings on everything else and everything feels fine now. I can run a bit faster on minimum to medium settings but it's not worth the trade off.)

This game needs lots of work still, so I'm glad I got it at an 80% discount. Since Steam forces me to choose, I'll give it a plus, but I'd rate it in the middle. There's some rare moments where the game will slow down and the animal animations can be glitchy rarely as well. I am running it on a laptop, so it could just be me, I wouldn't know. The track and blood direction will also sometimes but rarely be flipped in the opposite direction when pursuing an animal. I was really hoping this game would go deep into ballistics and gunsmithing, but I still don't know if this game even has bullet drop or wind drift, because it doesn't feel like it, and there's no gunsmithing. The controls also feel clunky. The game progression also feels off, but that's not a big deal. I'm pretty certain some animals become untrackable and just vanish. 

The scenery can look incredible at times, especially with the camera, so I hope the developers work on the camera some more. The closest thing to a camera simulator I ever played was Pokemon X of all things, so there's opportunity here to monopolize on this. There's huge potential with the camera. The animals seem programmed well enough for my own satisfaction, but I live in the city, so I have little experience with the personalities and mannerisms of large wild animals. I've seen deer in the Everglades and they just stare at you from a mile away, while alligators don't do much. The internet is full of wildlife hunting videos, so the deer, moose, and bears seem believable enough, except that they run away instead of attacking you. 

I haven't played a hunting game since MS-DOS/Win95, so I had little expectations. Hunting and fishing games have a reputation for being lacking and boring, but watching rifle review videos got me itching for a hunting game. theHunter: Call of the Wild really hooks you in, thankfully. If it was up to me, I do a complete overhaul to make the character progress feel more dynamic. Like stats for accuracy, reload speed, tree climbing, running, hide/leather crafting, etc. that you'd expect from an adventure game. There's also no knife in this game for knife enjoyers, but a machete could be a good game mechanic to work on. I should mention it's not a survival game, so it's not like you need to cook and build a fire, but it would be fun to have campfire making. Other players would probably hate for me to suggest firearm maintenance, but I would enjoy cleaning and oiling a rifle just to add more to the game, especially if it improved accuracy and reloading. Gun maintenance and customization is part of what makes hunting fun. 

The lack of weapons in this game is astounding to be honest. I don't know if more will come later or just a copyright issue, but there's a huge lack in selection. I thought this would be the type of game where you get to simulate different types of cartridges, barrels, and scopes, but it's severely limited. I was hoping this would be the one game that lets me use a rifle chambered in 7mm-08, but at least there's a 7mm in the game, so that's nice. The .308 in the game is good. Most of the pistols are revolvers to show you just how small the selection is. It's just a game though, so I wouldn't even care if the developers made up their own rifles and fantasy cartridges. Imagine hunting with PCC chambered in 9x29mm Winchester Magnum or something silly like that. Why not? 

In the end though, this is one of those games that you can probably play forever. There are some in-game tasks to give you more to do as well. Most time is spent walking and there's little dialogue and no story, so it's perfect for having a podcast playing in the background as you play this. The in-game noises and music are good too, but not mandatory for gameplay. I've been enjoying my time playing in Finland, as it's been very scenic and cozy. Most of the maps are in the form of DLC unfortunately, not all of which were included in my sale bundle. I would only recommend getting everything on sale because some DLC seems too expensive for what you get, such as weapon bundles. Asia isn't well represented, so I hope India or Thailand is coming next. I also played a little bit of Germany, which has really thick shrubbery and small animals, so it's not so fun. The Russian Taiga may be my favorite since it is easier than the other two due to the snowy landscape and large animals. Finland is a nice balance between the two. 

It's difficult trying to rate and review this game because I haven't played other games like it for comparison. Do I really recommend it? I'm not sure. On one hand, it's enjoyable as a game, but on the other, it feels very lacking as well. As a shooter game, I would have to say no, but as a nature game, I give it a yes. It's nice change of scenery and style compared to other shooter games that focus on stuff like humans vs monsters, so there's that if you want something more real world, but the lack of guns kind of dissapoints trying to do that well.

Never hunted before, don't need to - this game exists and I'm a city boy. Doesn't mean I don't enjoy the heck out of this game and wish I could really go hunting; not for sport mind you, only for food.

A little buggy sometimes but improves with updates. You get a lot of hours playing this game and you don’t even realize it. Because you’re hunting and following tracks for hours. Especially when you hit an animal and you start tracking the blood or you put him down right away depends on the shot. You want to try to get a vital shot with the proper ammo so you can get a Diamond. Know if it wasn’t a diamond or a gold it means there was something wrong either you shot the animal with the wrong weapon/bullets because each rifle has classes for which animal and you need the bullets that match it. You feel like you can get bored easily but that’s when you can’t find animals. It is also very easy to scare them away. They flee once they hear footsteps you must be careful and not shift. There are lots of nice maps with different kinds of animals in them and there are updates to this date with new maps and new animals. Make sure to buy them when they go on sale that is when it’s worth it. Also some DLC weapon packs, etc. but it’s a very good feeling when you hunt one. To enjoy this game you need to be patience. Also you can try different maps playing multiplayer with other people keeping up the score of who hunts the most. But If you don’t own any of the maps that you are playing as long as the owner of the map is still playing that’s no problem otherwise you only have 15 minutes then you’ll get kicked out.

This is a game I should've played back when it came out. Better late than never. While it isn't a perfect representation of hunting in video games, the overall experience is satisfying and sometimes great. There are plenty of challenges that await anyone who wants to jump into one of the many maps. The wide selection of animals and gear available makes theHunter a title you can spend many hours on. As an RPG, you have enough options to keep you interested, such as skills and perks. The variety of DLC gives you more options than you might ever need, providing even cosmetics to show off when playing online. While the game is fun solo, having a hunting buddy or an entire party turns this game into an absolute riot when things go well. There's nothing like ripping into a herd of elk to see them all go down for harvesting. Before I go on for too long about all the details, I will wholeheartedly recommend this game.

Have been into this for about 50 hours so far and I have to say I am really envying the game.   

Pros
* Great atmosphere and ambiance. Just walking around the countryside is interesting and relaxing.
* Good variety of weapons and equipment
* Pretty good animal behaviors makes finding game not too easy or too difficult.
* Tracking wounded animals is satisfying
* Maps are HUUUUGE
* Fun and well done multiplayer co-op

Cons
* Interface can be a bit clunky with managing inventory transferring items from storage to character
* Radial menu to is also a bit buggy at times but nothing game breaking once you get used to it
* Graphics are not breathtaking but get the job done
* Items are very expensive to earn using in-game currency, but frequent sales make getting some of the content pretty cheap.

All in all this is my favorite hunting game so far on the PC and can't wait to get into some of the other game reserves

I've been playing this game for a while now and I really love the combination of its beautiful environment and relaxing gameplay. However, I have noticed a particular issue that can be frustrating when I am hunting animals. Once I save an animal, I have no way of taxidermizing it later. Sometimes, I may not have enough money to do it immediately or I am hunting multiple animals at once, so I save the animal for later. Although I know that I can head straight to the lodge after a kill and taxidermize whatever I was hunting, but this can be difficult when the player doesn't have enough money as stated above. Therefore, I would appreciate it if the developers could add a feature that allows players to save the animals for later taxidermy. This feature would be a great addition to the game and would save players from the hassle of having to hunt down the same animal twice. Overall, I enjoy playing this game, but this one feature could use some improvement.

Spent 3 days installing this 85GB game, only to discover that most of the content is locked behind DLC. Why make me download and take up 85GB on my harddrive, if 90% of the game isn't even playable without DLC??

The game itself is fairly boring, and doesn't even live up to the depth of some original XBox games. Any animal can hear you snap a twig from hundreds of yards away, and somehow automatically know it's a human and flees. Your crouch movement speed is a snail's pace, but since it's the only way to not be a danger beacon to the animals in the area, you'll be spending most of the game at that speed. There's enclosures in the game that allow you to "camp out" and wait for animals, but it's pointless because you'll most likely be stuck there for irl hours waiting for anything to show up. The few items that are available to buy without DLC are absurdly expensive. I killed about 12 animals my first playthrough, and ended up around 8k. That took about 4-5 hours of gameplay....the average equipment upgrade costs between 5k-20k.

What's unfortunate is the moments where I was actually hunting and tracking something were enjoyable, and a part of me still wants to play because of that...but spending the vast majority of the game quietly shuffling from A to B ruins the experience for me. I don't care if it's "realistic". If I wanted to waste hours of my life to not have fun, I would just go hunting irl.

Probably one of the best hunting sim games I've ever played. The maps are huge and beautiful. The DLCs are worth the prices. Also if you seek a game where you can relax and enjoy a beautiful nature, this is a must have.

TL;DR: 9/10 - would recommend for hunting amateurs and pros. Quirky storytelling and a save-bug drained one point.

> Graphics: The game was released back in 2017 and playing it in 2024 it has really matured a whole lot. This game does not only sound nice, it also looks astonishing. From a graphics point of view I'd rate it a high AA-title.

> Mechanics: Ballistic curve, different calibers, different animal that need a specific approach each. It is nice. Tracking a wounded animal feels real but sometimes the animal despawn. That is the only uncool thing about hunting. This game is possible to be played as noob or pro alike.

> Storytelling: This is the only point I always found very annoying. Unskippable cutscenes and "calls" from someone I am not interested in listening to. If you want to completely immerse yourself, it is probably still a solid 7/10.

> Bugs: Saves. Saves is the biggest issue. Your guns and scores will be saved correctly but everytime you join a map everything is reset. You have to go and unlock all the houses - over and over again. There were none other bugs I came while playing this game.

Overall rating: 9/10 - besides the quirky storytelling and the save-bug I would highly recommend this game. You need some time and also a calm personality to play this game. If you are more a run and gun shooter guy - this game is probably not what you are looking for.

But this new generation of we sell you demo version is something I don't like to support. 

I did end up falling for the scam b/c its a pretty decent game, but I won't give it a thumbs up b/c the base game is basically a "bait"(Hunting pun). 

The main issue with the base game is that you cannot buy tents, or vehicles without spending another $15 at the time I'm writing this. Also the weapon selection is pretty poor. I feel sad that I fell into the trap. but if you go into the game knowing you're going to be nickle and dimmed at every turn then its a pretty good game. I just hate that they had my 2 hours and my $5 dollars before I realized I had been taken for a ride. 

So with that I would say if you don't want to be a rube like me move onto game makers who release complete games and not grindy BS to squeeze some dollars off you.

[h3]💬 Comments 💬[/h3]
[h2]Short Game Description[/h2]
theHunter: Call of the Wild is a realistic hunting game that features many huge reserves, most of which are behind a paywall but are worth it. The unique problem is the abusive DLCs and the little appreciation for the game that developers are giving.
[list]
[*][h3]Positives[/h3]
Discussing the positives, it has huge reserves based on real ones, which don't feel repetitive as you explore, and many unique animals that pertain to that area. Secondly, there are many weapons to pick from, and you can customise the loadout you will be using to hunt by creating some hunting areas, which the game forces you to not hunt all the time in the same area because there will be fewer and fewer animals if you hunt there so much. Thirdly, the animals are hard to encounter, and you will need to track them with footsteps, need zones, drinking zones, and sleep zones, which will be good spots to ambush the animals if you are sufficiently observant. Lastly, the game has some missions and spots with lore that make the game a bit more interesting to explore instead of just being a straightforward hunting game.
[*][h3]Negatives[/h3]
On the negative side, and the main complaint I have with the game, which is the reason I'm marking the game with a negative review, is that there are too many DLCs, most of which are quite essential, like some weapon packs, the ATV, the dog, tripods, and tents, that are not justified to be behind a paywall, as they are necessary, and some of them feature bugs, which makes the experience annoying and is not something uncommon; it was something I experienced through all the gameplay. The reserves deserve every euro spent, but most of the DLCs give a huge advance and don't take that much time to programme.
[/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2]
To conclude, the game has many good points, such as giving a realistic experience with many varieties and some interesting lore and quests in each reserve, but it is quite disappointing to see all the abusive DLCs that are not that hard to implement, some of which are essential to play, giving a huge advantage against players without them, and it is even worse when you pay for some of them and have constant bugs. The game, despite the abusive DLCs, is a 7.25/10.

[b] Gonna post an actual review for this one. [/b]

Having grown up hunting and being drastically disappointed by nearly every hunting game, theHunter: CotW is the only hunting game I've played that makes me ACTUALLY feel like I'm hunting. 

The gameplay is slow-paced and tactical, it requires you to either track animals stealthily and effectively, or familiarize yourself with their daily patterns and wait in a strategic spot/stand, and it relies on accurate vital shots to make kills. 

The game is far from perfect, has a handful of minor and major bugs, but the devs are active with fixing bugs and improving features from what I've seen. It's also a bit of a gamble whether the game will run BEAUTIFULLY or TERRIBLY on your machine. I've had PCs that were quite a bit under what I thought would even play the game run it like a charm, and I've had PCs that should be able to run fine lag so much the animations of everything were slowed down and I was playing the game in slow-mo. Still got a trophy elk that way, though.

BUT when this game runs right, it is an absolute dream of an experience. The gameplay loop is paced nicely, there's a very dynamic skill curve to hone over time with the gameplay loop in general, and it has quite a lot of skill curves to master for each particular strategy and piece of equipment. Each successful kill is extremely satisfying, each bad shot comes with its own challenges and opportunities to learn, and you can spend hours in the game just enjoying the scenery and it's still a relaxing experience. Hell, I've spent whole evenings just tracking a single animal and feeling more than satisfied enough for the night when I finally get it. It really does feel like hunting beautiful tracks of land. One of the best games [b] ever made [/b] for unwinding after a long day. 

[b] Tl;Dr Pros and Cons [/b]

[b] Pros: [/b]
- Actually feels like hunting
- Nicely paced gameplay loop, not too rushed, not too slow
- Beautiful scenery and graphics
- Deep skill curve
- Lots of different animals to hunt, all with their own strategies required
- Extremely relaxing and rewarding, no matter how you play the game
- Updated and bug fixed regularly

[b] Cons: [/b]
- Performance intensive
- Some machines just don't run it right
- Known bugs and issues. Some inconsequential, some hilarious, some awful
- DLC heavy, esp for duck hunting, displaying trophies, and additional locations
- Vitals system is extremely strict. Makes for great shot placement practice, but you can shoot something in the jugular and watch it just run away with a "No vitals hit" message bc the jugular does not count as a vital organ :|
- Shotguns shoot like 10-20 pellets max, so duck hunting is often a total joke.

This game has mind-blowing graphics and brilliant representation but lacks basic gameplay mechanics.

I would like to see below gameplay changes and hope that EW will consider my suggestions to bring substantial improvements in the game. 

1. Main/side missions appear too hard 
2. Training modules
3. Demos or In-game strategy tutorials 
4. Map improvements  
5. Add more zones and more animals 
6. Inventory improvements 
7. Make rest times free
8. Game save feature 


1. The side mission says "harvest 2 blacktail deer in Balmont" but when you go to any nearby ponds in Balmont during blacktail deer drink times 1600-2000 there you will see no deers around in any drink zones. Putting pointers around drink zones on the map or mobile will also help the player, but they are not available. Introduce a radar HUD screen or a separate animal tracker that clearly shows the location of all nearby animals i.e. where they are resting/feeding/drinking. Add difficulty levels to the game - Easy, Medium and Hard. This should resolve most of the problems mentioned.

2. Tutorials on how to hunt different animals. I know this is a big ask but it is definitely going to help new players even if we can cover one animal from each class.
I think the highest class is 9. So, nine tutorials with tips should be sufficient to get any new player familiarised with training and along with this you can introduce ranking, trophies, ammo selection and any advanced topics in the tutorials itself before pushing player towards the main game.

3. In-game tutorials need to be available. How to track deer steps? What is the approx. safe distance to maintain? Which scopes/guns or ammo to use for an effective kill? 
It is unreasonable to expect from a player to experiment with all these just to analyse which is better or worse, that will be a waste of time.

4. In the map section, if you click Legend it will show all zones or other markings but the data is not organised in a way that could help the player. For instance, in the legend say 15 items are there (rest zone, drink zone, home, tent icons etc) and the player wants to have an ability to filter what they want to see on the map rather than seeing all junk that is available. Player may like to see only tents or bear tracks for example without having to see 100 icons on the map. A filter will be useful here.

5. Basically, there are very less number of animals corresponding to a mission. In the mission that I have mentioned earlier in step #1 harvest two blacktail ... it was way too difficult to spot any deers, not even during the time zone, not near any drink or feed zones. Guess this is the case with all the other missions. For instance, when you are on a coyote hunting mission, the game isn't showing you at least 10 coyotes wandering nearby the mission area for you to hunt. 

6. I bought a lot of ammo worth over $1000.00, but I didn't realise it was incompatible with the guns that I already own. This rendered the newly purchased ammo to be useless and my cash wrongly spent. The worst thing is that I can't even trade ammo back for cash or for any other category of ammo. That's a shame! I expect the game to prevent me from buying any ammo which isn't compatible with the guns that I own, or at least it should show me a list of guns only that are compatible with the ammo. Either ways when you purchase a gun, the system should show you all the information about which ammo is compatible and which isn't; vice-versa should also be true i.e. when purchasing ammo (all compatible guns need to be displayed). A proper table with select-able options and columns is all what is needed here.

7. Why do you need to spend $250.00 at an outpost to sleep? Isn't that supposed to be free? A new player will keep losing whatever little cash that they had earned only to be spent for resting at outposts. In my opinion, resting needs to be made free as a means of going back to the saved time instead of restarting the whole mission again. I think that is the only chance one can get their time back without spending cash at the moment.

8. There should be a feature to allow saving game progress to a savepoint. The player doesn't have to fiddle with time going backward or forward. Just introduce a game save feature that will allow a player to go directly to that savepoint. If they had forgotten to do something, they can continue the game from there anytime.
