I've been this game on and off for a while now and I have to say its a very relaxing game. The game has very smooth game play and I find the story line very interesting. In my opinion I find the leveling balanced (not to fast, not to slow) along with earning money. Its not a game you'll beat in a day especially if your going  to run through all the story lines on all the maps and with that being said its a slower paced game overall. I love that they made weapon classes for all the animals and weapons in the game. The trophy lodges are a very nice touch I feel. I enjoy using the different tactics available to harvest my game whether its sitting in a treestand or stalking game through the brush. The wind can blow your scent in the wrong direction causing your prey to spook or they could hear you moving through the brush if your moving to quickly. Overall I love this game and it will continue to be a game I keep playing. I highly recommend this game to anyone who enjoys hunting.
The Things I Really Like:
-herd management
-variety of weapons and maps (if you purchase the weapon and map packs)
-story line on each map
-the look and feel of the game (map detail and fluid game play)
-the variety of animals from rabbits up to bison and unique animals like piebald deer and cinnamon bears
-the tracking and following blood trails

Things I Really Don't Like
-the ballistics seem kinda wonky, I don't feel like a lot of the calibers are given the power they deserve
-animals seem to run to far for a vitals shot (but that could be me being a crappy shot)

This game is fantastic but there are issues. 

Sound issues such as birds repeating and glitching out. 
Sound direction is a bit off from time to time. 
Auto save has had issues and I've seen this is common for others. I lost about 3 hours of game play which is super frustrating, gold harvests lost, close calls with buffaloes and lions, skills, traits and purchases all gone. Second time this has happened and a third time lucky I'll just uninstall it and request money back. No matter how good the game is, if you can't progress its not worth playing. A hard save feature or option outside of auto save could fix this. 
There could also be an indication while hunting that shows you your weapon/calibre may not be suitable for harvesting that particular animal. I do appreciate how this is not limited though, making it more realistic. 

I've only played one map, but good things are difficulty, animal behaviours, tracking is fun, weapon choice is great and graphics are nice. 
Both animals and players leave imprints in grass which is a nice touch. 
Animals actually attack you and kill you forcing you to re-spawn which is a bit more realistic and humbles you. 
Voice overs from characters are a nice touch and well done.

I have played the game for over 4 years & waited a long time to give a positive review, but that day has not come.  Arbitrary rules prevent it from being a great game. Arbitrary rules for 'game balance.'  Balance for whom, exactly?  It certainly isn't balanced for me, the player.  It is designed to limit your options & perpetuate the grind.  My purpose is not to bash the game or the Devs.  I really want it to be a great game, but I don't want to be manipulated, controlled into hunting a certain way.  Here are some of the changes needed:
1-EW changed spook radius with the last update & did not even mention it in patch notes.  Two issues with this: a-It was not broken & needs to be rolled back, b-Changing fundamental game mechanics without telling players is an unethical, unacceptable practice.  It must stop.

2-Carry Weight - I always carry a tent but you are severely penalized because it weighs 6 units.  This is a hike in the woods & hunting game so it is totally reasonable to carry a tent.  But, it currently precludes you from carrying all the other gear you need.  A weight of 2-3 units would be acceptable.   Backpacks with the noise & visibility penalty are a joke & not a viable alternative. Another case is the high tech bow sight with a ridiculous weight.  I did not buy that DLC because of it.

3-Ammo Class - It needs to be a broader range in many cases to be inline with hunting norms.  My pet peeve caliber is the 270 as it is my RL favorite.  It is not competitive in its current class of 4-8.  It weighs more than the M1 30-06 & is less effective.  It needs to be class 2-7 along with the 6.5 mm.  There is nothing unethical about shooting a class 2 coyote with a 270.  It is realistic & reasonable.  The 270 is one of the great hunting calibers & deserves more than being a locker queen or having its trophies unfairly penalized.  Other poor decisions include the muzzle loader which should be good for class 9 & the 300 needs to be for class 5-9.  Again, there is nothing unethical about shooting a 500 lb red deer with the 300.  These are artificial, arbitrary restrictions & not in any way based on reality.

4-Render distance is way too short at 400 m.  700 m would be more appropriate.  Maybe have a setting for normal & long so that lower end PCs can still use the 400 m.

5-Ballistics is grossly under powered in some cases.  The worst offenders are buckshot & 223 which have been way too weak forever.

6-The hunting pressure mechanism punishes the player for stalking on foot compared to blinds or tripods.  Stalkers should have the same reduced pressure.  

7-The economy is ridiculous & perpetuates the grind.  Tripods at 16,000 coins, blinds at 8,000, etc.  Cutting all prices in half would at least move it closer to being balanced.

8-The bleat caller is the only one for mule deer.  It needs to be at least 200 m.

9-Pheasants were a great addition but the implementation was not.  I gave up on getting them to fly & just ignore them.  How about if you whistle they fly?

10-Attacked in a Blind or Stand - These need to give you the same protection as a tripod.  I don't even bother to setup decoys & blinds on a map like Parque because you get attacked by buffalo while trying to hunt ducks.  Its just plain silly.

11-Animal Aggression - It is the most unrealistic, overdone, arcade feature of the game.  I have hunted in RL for over 50 years & no one I know has ever been attacked by a wild animal.  Not once, not ever.  Yes, it does happen but it is rare. Some days it can be fun fending off animals that want to kill you, but most of the time I don't want it.  Since a lot of people apparently like the survival game, we need an option to turn it on or off.

12-LOS - Animals should not have xray vision & be able to see you through trees, bushes, hills that are between you & them.  I suspect that changing it would be very difficult, maybe impossible with the current engine. 

If EW finally listens to average players like me & makes these changes I will not hesitate to change my review.  But, if they continue down the path of poor design choices like over the top animal aggression, not allowing my beloved 270 the ammo class it realistically deserves, then I am not going to like their final product.  For now, I don't trust that they will listen & change, & I will not spend anymore money on the game until they do.  The game design is too restrictive for my playstyle & it is not moving in my direction.  Edit: It is more than a year since my review & they have  not listened.  I still don't want to play it.

A number of people on both sides of my family hunt and take it very seriously. I belong to the type of family that takes photos of hunts or buys paintings of hunting doves, deer, duck, etc. I recently ate "poppers" made with birds that had been shot a few days ago.

It was inevitable I would like this sim/game. This game gets a lot right. I'm curious about some things involving the realism (like whether certain animals congregate around water bodies or predators around areas with a high density of prey). I am a bit put off by the cheesy dialogue, but it is what it is. At least the gameplay is good. Siberia and Alaska maps are great. Shooting bears is challenging.

If I go hunting in the next year, I'll be sure to update this review to compare the real experience vs this sim.

Hello there, dear reader!
First off, thanks a bunch for checking out my review – I truly appreciate it! Let's dive straight into some insights about this captivating GAME (after all, that's why you're here, right?)
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
I don't want this REVIEW to be so long, so I will write it short as I can. ★

► Graphics ( 10 ) - [b]You will be in love with graphics:) this game is perfectly designed for photographs.[/b]
► Physics ( 8 ) - [b]In sometimes, you will get stuck in any places or mobs.[/b]
► Gameplay (  9 ) - [b]Is pretty nice. You have to do some missions and of course to make RIFLE POINTS, HUNTING POINTS for unlock some guns, items in general.[/b] 
► Multiplayer / CO-OP experience ( 10 ) - [b]It's a great experience to play with a friend or with others.[/b]
► Shoting ( 8 ) - [b]I don't know what I should add here... but in sometimes I can't understand why I cannot hit, for example, a deer if I'm sure that I put the scope on it? By the way, the game presents a interesting recoil on guns ( a realistic one )[/b]

I recommend this game! 
But I recommend it more to be played with someone!

I'm posting this in late 2023, almost 7 years after its release. I've been waiting for so long for them to fix many of these issues. I'll update this regularly as I encounter bugs. Some issues occur only in multiplayer, and I mainly play with friends.

Bugs:

-Lots of audio issues. Something sounds left when its actually right. Hearing constant foot steps from a fixed location when nothing is there. My players own foot steps vanishing completely. Completely incorrect sound levels for a distance. These issues vary from annoying to game breaking. I usually experience 1 to 2 audio issues per session, the longer the session the worse some issues become.
- Bobcats scream volume is 10000% from all distances.

-DLC dogs tend to disappear and become useless 1 to 2 times per session. Reloading to a different area usually fixes it. This bug is well known to the developers.

-Desync in multiplayer is a common issue, fairly well known. The longer the session, the more bugs and issues you'll likely encounter.

-Guns tend to disappear until you fast travel, happening once every 2 to 3 sessions. This has been a known bug for a long time.

-The middle mouse button quick select sometimes stops switching ammo type and scope when using Q or E. To fix it, you must select an empty loadout (which is locked to 5) and teleport to the infinite ammo gun range. Then, teleport back to your previous location and select your previous loadout. However, this doesn't always work. It occurs about every hour, rendering the new function practically useless. This issue has been reported by the community about 8 months ago and affects all my friends.

-Animals tend to glitch out and stay in place, sometimes becoming unkillable. This has been a long-time known issue occurring 3 to 6 times per session.

-ATVs drive as if they're on ice, displaying poor physics. It seems unlikely they will ever fix this.

-Animal view distance is locked at 400 yards. If you were hoping for long-distance hunting, your only option is mods. Developers actively try to impede mods.

Personal issues with the game and Devs:

-They disdain mods and actively attempt to disrupt the modding community by pushing malicious updates. If only they put as much effort into fixing bugs as they do in thwarting modders. Unofficial patch mods, such as those for the Elder Scrolls Series, could have fixed most of the bugs by now. It appears the devs have ego issues and can't stand others fixing their own failures. Quite disappointing.

-Constantly releasing DLC without fixing the base game is poor form. Maybe they'll release an Official Patch DLC to fix all the mods. I wouldn't be surprised if this idea crossed their mind.

-I'd like more content beyond just hunting exclusives. Make the game more interesting by adding more vehicles, campers, campfires, or even releasing a survivalist DLC (after addressing common bugs, of course).

-Scopes are tinted green and grainy, which is puzzling. Mods can fix this, but they don't always work.

-Birds and many animals don't behave correctly, making the hunting simulation feel blatantly gamey and unrefined.

-I'd appreciate more settings to customize the game.

-Tracking and stealth mechanics feel odd and very gamey.

-They should have integrated their fishing game into this one. Hunting and fishing in the same game would be enjoyable.

The good:
Unfortunately, it's currently the best hunting co-op simulation available. It offers many maps, diverse animals, and continues to be updated with pay-locked content. It's enjoyable, but every session is frustrating in one way or another.

DISCLAIMER: This game is almost unreasonably glitchy. Especially the multiplayer CAN get downright broken, especially if some higher ping individuals are involved. New updates release with bugs that are obvious to anyone who plays for 10 minutes. I have no clue how the devs manage to do this little QA.

Despite that...

This is one of my favourite games I played in the last few years. Getting together with some good friends and setting out to kill some of god's creations is a near unrivaled experience. This is definitely not a game for everyone however. 

You need at least two of these:
- be a gun nut
- enjoy nature walks and pretty environments
- enjoy dopamine-detox video games
- have great conversationist friends
- have some disposable income for DLC
- have an above-average tolerance for bugs and general jank

Assuming this suits you, I cannot recommend this game enough. Despite everything it is a stellar experience and I have high hopes that the devs will address the issues as they seem to care quite a bit.

I left a negative Steam review because I found the game boring - as it turns out, the level I picked in Europe was apparently the hardest one in the game, so I did the one in the US and I was actually finding wildlife and able to hunt them successfully. It wasn’t you, it was me. Unfortunately I have already refunded it on Steam, but I am currently playing via Game Pass for PC and I’m having a significantly better time. The only thing I would say is, don’t lead with the quest to take a photo of the red deer. I agree with not having where animals reside on the map to increase the difficulty, but I think that pushes you into the deep end too quickly. I think that may have been the source of my frustration, coupled with my inexperience with the game.

$19.99 for this game is a joke. If you can buy it on sale for $3.99, its "ok" but with how much DLC is shoved down your throat, this game should be free. Most guns and items in the store are locked behind DLC. Maps are locked behind DLC. Quality of life updates like better ways to traverse the map via 4-wheelers or the praised "tent" system which allows you to fast travel to a previous point you have been, locked behind DLC's. I cannot give this a good review when the direction of the game is to charge you for every quality of life update. It's bad business, and it's sad, because at its core, this is a solid and well made game.

-some DLC are just greedy 
-since they gave progression and economy away the only longterm motivation to play is getting the bigger antlers which means RNG-hunting for legendaries until your brains fall out and that's it - and not even that is for free. The proper lodge to display your legendary kills is a paid DLC, which is outrageous if you think about it how you have to buy the longterm motivation to play as a seperate DLC.
-Directional sound is entirely broken which hurts immersion a lot. 

6/10

Provides a good hunting experience in nice environments if stalking deer is your thing but don't expect anything outside of that. It only reaches the bare minimum of what you'd expect for the price. 
Most of all hurts the bad UI, bad optimazation on AMD and very underdeveloped RPG mechanics imo. 
It's one of those games that is a simulation more than anything and fun is clearly an afterthought. 
It tries to be a hunting simulator and it achieves that for as long as you're not aiming for headshots since the head is no "vital organ" in this game. What you get is a product for the niche audience that are already entrenched in the topic. Nothing for a casual player or even RPG-player. 

tl,dr: 
could have been a great game but falls short. Only recommended to absolute hunting nerds since it is still in a bare bones state even after all these years and they still try to milk every dollar possible from it.

This game is exactly what you'd expect and if you like open world games where you run around a ton, this is for you. I eventually caved and bought the 4 wheeler DLC but spent probably my first 100 hours without it, maybe more. It does get tedious after a while, but not so much that it made me want to quit the game. You get to see cool scenery and shoot whatever you want so it's fine. There are some glitches and bugs here and there, it's whatever. Love the ability to have trophy rooms and there's a lot of extra DLC content if you want. For paying usually less than $10 per game you get so much bang for your buck without any of the DLC content like guns and dogs. I've played most of the different DLC hunting settings and enjoy the change in scenery and huntable creatures. It is sometimes very annoying and challenging to hunt the small game creatures for achievements or story progression since they're hard to hit and even see, but usually you can pick and choose which quests to keep going and which ones to give up on if you're not having fun. Overall I continue to enjoy it and come back to it every once and a while and would recommend.

If you're planning on buying the game- don't, even if its discounted(unless you're in only for the boring type of hunt). Its my honest opinion, knowing that more than 50% of the game contents are locked behind DLCs;  all the quads, all the hunting dogs, 90 % of the maps(you only get to play 2 for free), the tents, the "good" weapons.. everything i mentioned is only portrayed in the steam page under a "cute" showcase banner to attract as much money in as they can, and also all the items i mentioned aren't obtainable UNLESS you SPECIFICALLY "open that fucking wallet WIDE OPEN"(- probably what their marketing lead said). 
      It's a really empty base game that gets boring after your first 4 hours of walking down to checkpoints(yes, its a running simulator since any other means of transportation other than your feet are PAID!!). 
The base game feels like a free demo, but the jest is that it's NOT FREE AT ALL . But hats off for some good qualities of the game, like the graphics and the lore, even tho unfortunately, as said, the OUTRAGEOUS marketing strategy bathes completely the game in mud. 
      I just hope the developers earn some dignity, by either selling one single product(the base game + all the DLCs) at a higher price point, or, by atleast making a good 90% of the game contents unlockable through some kind of in-game earnable currency.

Played this game on and off for a few years now. Usually re-download it on a whim and then spend the next few months just playing this game.

Pros.
- All the reserves look amazing even on low graphics settings.
- Not too hard of a learning curve. Classic easy to learn, hard to master type of game.
- Incredible satisfaction when you down an animal with a perfect shot after stalking it for ages.

Cons.
- Some paid DLC items could have easily just been updates to the game like the blind and hunting stands.
- The story on the Silver ridge peaks reserve doesn't require any hunting, just run from point of interest to point of interest.
- Sometimes the sound of animal calls can be off in terms of direction. Even a few degrees out can send you way off target with your stalking.

Overall I actually love this game, six years on and they are still adding decent new reserves to the game so it doesn't get boring. There's a type of game to hunt for everyone, from ducks and geese all the way to crocodiles and cape buffalo with a huge mixture in between.

Amazing game, you never get bored and it's hyper relaxing. Don't expect to do all achievements in a few days, even if you go 24 24. When I'm writing this I have about 118h and I got it from a half year back, I don't grind so this is pretty much. Recommended DLCs: Some reserves, I like yukon, then on cuatro carolina you get two free diamonds (misson). Te Aworora is a great reserve for beginners and pros. Weapon Pack DLCs: Modern Rifle Pack, grat startr pack, Zarza 308. covers the most animals (4-8). The other weapons in that pack works fine, but nothing beats Zarza. Smoking Barrels: The second Pack recommended, Muzzeloader with Miller Model 1891. Miller is a fantastic weapon to hunt with, you can hunt all from the greatest animals to the teeny tiny animals. Fire three shots in no time; That's Miller Model 1891. Other recommended DLCs: ATV, soooo useful. A hunting loge of your choice, I like Spring Greek Manor.  Treestands And Tripods, what can i say, kill eight animals instead of four to delete a zone. Bloodhound; How elese do you find your diamond? High Tech Pack; I don't know about you but I prefer to see in the dark!

Tips: Join a discord server to see hotspots (where animals drink). LadyLegend's server is great for everyone that wanna know the fur type rarity and when they drink. Pro XCK's  server is OP for hotspot. When you shot an animal aim a little above the front leg. Watch youtube you can learn a lot from that, but be careful, watch things you learn from and not always it just for fun. Follow my recommendations and you will improve fast.

I just looked this game up because I want to play a hunting game, but apparently I've already played it in the past and forgot when and for how long. I'm playing The Angler right now and it's reminding me of a hunting sim I didn't like and I'm pretty sure it was this one. 

It's a very pretty game that goes extremely in-depth with how the animals react to you. Deer will hear you loudly bushwhacking from 200 metres away, so you have to sneak while tracking game. They'll smell you if you're upwind, so you have to try and remain downwind of them while you do so. It's an extremely good hunting simulator that they've put a lot of thought and effort into, and it's absolutely not a game for me. 

If they added realism/difficulty settings to the game, I might give it a solid go, but I just don't want to go slow and steady and spend 20 minutes hunting a single animal. So here I am redownloading Red Dead Redemption 2 where I can ride across the countryside on my horse and the most thought I have to put into hunting is "better use a different gun, this one will ruin the pelt".

I had 46 hrs into the game with that amount of game progress, the next day I log into the game I encountered a problem wherein the game freezes halfway through the beginning loading screen. I thought of it as a no big deal since, surely there's going to be numerous ways on fixing the said problem. But after I tried those "ways" the problem didn't fix, rather they did get temporarily "fixed" wherein it worked for the first time but after I log out and log back in the problem occurs again. I did everything everyone such as deleting certain files in the avalanche folder (ofc i made a backup file just in case) but nah didn't fix, tried unchecking some DLC's, nope didnt work. Reinstalling the game, nope don't work, updated drivers? nah doesn't matter, try to min max RAM usage, nope doesn't work either. I had added like at least 20 more hrs trying to fix this problem but it doesn't want to be fixed.

Oh yeah here's the kicker as well, when I was trying to fix the problem my original save that had 46 hrs worth of progress disappeared PLUS the fact that this problem has been an re occurring problem since the day this game was released is stupid. So you're telling me all throughout that years of developing this problem wasn't fixed yet?

I wanted to enjoy the game, I really do, and I did have fun, I enjoyed the realistic hunting experience this game provided. But now ever since the problem I had showed up, every session I put into the game is just a waste of time.

So thanks, that first 46 hrs of experience has now become an experience I wanted to experience again but has now became a pipe dream

Im a hunter, born and raised, I reload all my own ammo and used to be sponsored by mathews and hoyt as a kid. Was really into archery then. I found this game about a year ago and said hey lets just check it out. I didnt get to play it a whole lot but when I did I found it to be surreal. yeah sure the game misses some aspects like the field dressing, dragging, quartering and what not. but overall the game is really realistic, amazing graphics, well balanced guns, stalking and calling, ect. ITS BEAUTIFUL. but it does have its flaws, moose and 7mm seem to not mix very well. pretty sad. Mule deer racks suck, absolutely terrible on that part, and it misses out on a lot of great decoys, vehicles, guns and callers. now I understand you cant have everything, especially branded guns, but with what little it has it still makes the most. so its fair to say it gets a 8.7/10. if the devs somehow ever see this just know I would be very well willing to help with future ideas. no pay just help. I absolutely love the game. and its a great way to teach friends the basics of hunting without field practice. anyway thats my word. IF ANYONE wants help getting into the game, just dm me on disc or steam (discord Vapora#3414)

I love this game. The only thing i would like to have change in the game is the reactions and behavior of the predators. such as interaction with brown bears, in reality they will charge and attack if you get to close and stalk you if they pick up your scent. how ever in the game they run away. The wolves are semi the same as brown bears with the exception that wolves hunt in packs. They also stalk and size up their prey by testing the boundaries and threat level. It would also be a neat feature to see the predators chase down their prey versus seeing just leftover scraps on the ground. I have recently had friends by this game to play with me. The game in general is amazing! Beautiful landscape and wonderful world building in general. What i wish for future dlc’s or updates is that they add more veachles, the quadbike is good indeed but it’s just basic, i mean like they could maybe add an upgrading system for it (accesories like a storage contain ect. And also a basket for your dog). I also would like to have longer stories since the outer parts of the maps doesn’t get explored if there isen’t a piece of story there. The stories also introduces us to what it would be like to live on those maps, there are cases of animal attacks and other things going on. Now for my final wish: the lack of human or ai/npc interactions. Now some people will say that they don’t need any human interaction, but for some people it may be different. It can maybe make people feel safe while playing all alone, knowing that there is someone in there that they can talk too. 

But all in all this game is a 9.5/10 and would definetly recommend as a first choice for new gamers using steam.

I wont make this too long. There are plenty of more in depth reviews on this game. I would say most of them are pretty accurate. I come from the point of view of having first played TheHunter Classic. I started playing that game when it first came out and was blown away at the time with the detail. Because at that time it was one of, if not, the best hunting games available. TheHunter Call of the Wild is in my opinion a fresh take on the classic. The maps are great. The animals are decent.  There are some things I like from both games. There are also some things I don't like. Go figure. 
 In general though I think that the team behind this game has done a wonderful job. I know that the AI for the animals could be better. But how many of us playing this game have actually tried to make a realistic animal in a game? I know I haven't. I can imagine that it is not easy and at some point you just have to move on with working on other parts of the game. 
I find it plenty good enough to fend off my hunting cravings. 
Also to put something into perspective. I am one of those people who DOES NOT spend money on games. I find it stupid and honestly a waist of money. I BOUGHT ALMOST ALL OF THE DLCs for this game. I will probably finish buying the rest a bit later. So for if it's good enough to make me spend my hard earned money on. It's at least worth trying out for all your dedicated gamers out there. 
Good job to the developers. I look forward to seeing what comes next.

Not only are numerous necessary features locked behind DLC, but the DLC are filled with bugs and/or are incomplete. The developers do not seem to care about this game at all.

Many of the maps will get old fast. In locations where you should be able to encounter dozens upon dozens of unique animals, you can only find the short list that they added instead.

The Yukon Valley is one of the most extraordinary places on earth with a goldmine of biodiversity. We could have all kinds of birds, deer, sheep, goats, lynx, bear, and even beavers. Look up Alaskan wildlife if you want to know just how much should be in the game. Instead, the devs added the following: Harlequin Duck, Canada Goose, Red Fox, Gray Wolf, Caribou, Grizzly Bear, and Moose.

For the Yukon Valley of Alaska, they gave us a grand total of... seven animals. Every single map is like this, they are all severely lacking in biodiversity, finishing touches, and story.

Almost every single weapon in the game is broken or bugged in one way or another. Almost across the board iron sights are improperly modeled, sometimes to the point that they will make you unable to properly see your target. DLC content isn't safe from this either, it's like every single gun was modeled by a different person who knew nothing about how to actually aim one. It's a genuine mess and forces you to use a scope which you can't even zero in a way that makes sense.

You will spend hours walking to get from one place to another unless you spend more real money to buy an ATV. It's ridiculous that something so necessary is locked behind a paywall.

I bought most of the DLC, and only then did the game start to feel slightly more complete.

The animals have terrible instincts, but this flaw is much harder to fix because they have to constantly adapt to both the player, the map, and their set schedules so I find it less egregious. All of this will conflict and cause animals that run right to you or fail to run away correctly, allowing for such easy kills that it's like shooting fish in a barrel. It completely removes the challenge as well as the immersion.

My final gripe is less important, but if all else were perfect then I would of course prefer this to be fixed as well. Ballistics aren't realistic at all. Much of this is likely due to balance, but sometimes when you view the path of the bullet into the animal it's just stupid how quickly it stops in the animal. Even a rabbit can stop a .22 like it's Luke Cage after hardly any penetration at all, or a deer can prevent a .243 from reaching its' heart through the front with only a fistfull of fat and hide.

Mistakes are understandable, but the developers have left these problems as they are FOR YEARS. They don't care about the game, and it isn't going to get better.

🐻 The first impression of the game was not the best; long wanderings through the forests were tiring. 🐾Nature, of course, is at the highest level, sounds, wind, chirping birds. But over time, this game became addictive, 
when the necessary abilities are pumped up, hunting becomes easier and more interesting, you no longer rush through the bushes🌳 at breakneck speed to rush a bison or a white-tailed deer🦌, but you wait steadfastly for it to come to you. 
I liked the game. 
💢 Yes, there are bugs in it, animals get stuck, or run cyclically in circles, there were wild boars that rushed around the location like a bullet, but people are eager to fix this crap if possible, for me personally this is not critical. 
🌐There is an online game where you can hunt and drive game together with your friends. Of course, there are not enough birds, I would add ducks, quails, pheasants, etc., 
🔫 Weapons. There are many types of rifles, there are shotguns, a pistol, a crossbow, and a bow. In principle, if not strong critics of hunting, then a very useful game. I recommend it to everyone).
-
💢About the maps, I feel like most of the maps are the same, Most of them have exactly the same details. When you walk around the forests or areas with each addition, you feel as if the game developer is just copying and pasting areas and then spreading them randomly as if they are new.

125 hours in with 0 diamonds yet and for some reason I'm still having fun. Love this game!

Edit: 1 Great One and 10 Diamonds later my trophy lodge is looking nice, but I have a couple of complaints about the trophy system that would really make trophy hunting much better.

1. More rack variations, it seems like every species racks are almost similar all around, not much variety, you can shoot a silver and gold whitetail with almost identical racks, 1 just looks a little bigger.

2. Trophy lodges should have most spots be able to change wall plaques, I don't hunt enough small game to fill every small plaque in the lodge and I've been out of space for large animals for a while now.

3. Let me attach a nickname to my trophies i.e "My First Diamond" or "Spent 2 hours stalking this guy" so I can remember why i taxied some of them and put them on the wall.

This game is amazing, anybody who loves hunting would enjoy this, I personally just want to see a better trophy system and it would be a 10/10 for me.

The Hunter: Call of the Wild delivers a truly captivating hunting experience set amidst beautifully rendered, expansive landscapes. The game's attention to detail, from the lush forests to the diverse wildlife, creates a sense of immersion and realism that is unparalleled in the hunting genre.

What sets The Hunter: Call of the Wild apart is its dedication to authenticity. The game's realistic animal behaviours, dynamic weather systems, and lifelike environments contribute to a deeply immersive hunting experience. Whether tracking majestic deer, elusive predators, or majestic birds, the thrill of the hunt is beautifully captured.

The game's open-world exploration allows players to roam freely across vast terrains, offering a sense of freedom and discovery. The variety of weapons, gear, and hunting tactics available cater to different playstyles, encouraging strategic approaches to tracking and taking down prey.

The Hunter: Call of the Wild's solo or multiplayer modes provide options for both solitary hunting experiences and cooperative adventures with friends. Regular updates and expansions continue to enrich the game, ensuring that there's always something new to explore and hunt.

For hunting enthusiasts seeking a realistic and immersive hunting simulation, The Hunter: Call of the Wild offers an unparalleled experience, transporting players to breathtaking wilderness settings for an unforgettable hunt.

The Hunter Call of the Wild (THCOTW) is a stellar hunting game. Despite being 6 years old, the game is beautiful, with good graphics, very detailed maps & hunting options & interesting missions. In fact, the game is so beautiful & enjoyable, I mostly just play the game as a hiking simulator, to be out in nature, rather than to hunt. So overall, the game is very well done.

However, the game has a longstanding problem: the developers refuse to add endangered species. This means that players miss out on seeing many iconic animals, like tigers, elephants, & rhinos. 

I want to get the developers' attention & motivate them to better serve we, the players. I know there are many other players who feel the same way I do. IMO, the developers are selling short themselves and the players by not including endangered animals.

Developers, with all due respect, we, the players, pay your salaries & make your work possible. I hope that you'll reconsider your decision to not include endangered animals. The players are demanding it & if you don't serve us, then we'll go to a game that will & you'll suffer the negative consequences, including financial losses.

There are viable workarounds that could address the moral issue of including endangered animals in the game. Please use them. Simply add a disclaimer or warning when the game begins: "Warning, hunting endangered animals is illegal and immoral. We condemn such behavior...". Lots of games have disclaimers, like Wreckfest and House Party.

Also developers, you could add the option to toggle hunting endangered animals in the settings. That way, players could choose. As well, maybe make hunting endangered animals conservation missions.

I want to see/hunt a tiger, my favorite animal. I saw some data a few years ago that showed that the tiger was the most popular animal on the planet. And here we have a good game with lots of animals and no tigers? It doesn't make sense to me. Better to serve your customers by adding endangered animals. 

I’m physically disabled, so I’ll likely never get to see a wild tiger in real life. But I could have a similar experience in this game, if endangered animals were added. In short, this game could be the closest I can get to the experience of seeing my favorite animal in the wild. And yet, it’s unavailable because endangered animals are not in the game. Developers, do you see why this issue is important to me? Do you see why the lack of endangered animals in the game is so disappointing? I strongly hope that you’ll reconsider & add endangered animals to the game.

Developers, until you add endangered animals, we're left with a very good game that unfortunately could have been so much more; a game that could have provided me with an experience I’ll never get in real life (seeing a wild tiger) but didn’t.

In conclusion, overall I recommend the game, as long as you don't mind a game that falls short of its potential; a game that's missing many iconic animals.

The worlds on the other hand are MASSIVE.  It takes a long time to walk around and often get bored a little walking and side tracking to look for fun stuff.  You can fast travel to a safe house if you got them unlocked, but that is ONLY once you unlocked it. Which is fine I guess to explore and find the markers. 

There are no vehicles included with the base game, but are now a DLC.  When I bought this game, there was no vehicles and now they have added ATV's (Three different colours) but they are a DLC item... Too which I bought and really makes the game feel more and more like hunting and exploring! This DLC I feel is a must to have!

The game has also adds tents, but this again is a DLC... It does not improve your game as such and can be missed if wanted.

This is a slow paced game, so no run and gun.  Expect to take a long time, going slow (Which is often frustrating for me at times because it feels so slow I need to sprint)

Would I recommend this game? If you are a big fan of hunting games and want something that is going to draw you in and keep you focused and enjoy a slow pace simulation style game then this is the game for you!

I am swinging towards a 78% yes because it is unique and offers a fun amount of hours in the game! It is also multiplayer which is a lot more fun as we know with others.  Just the bugs are slightly annoying right now, limited hunting is a little off putting, otherwise good job!

They’ve also done a good job in adding more content and zones to explore.

Once again I'm left wishing Steam had a neutral option. There's a lot I enjoy about this game, and it feels wrong to vote it down; I LOVE the environments, atmosphere, sound design and attention to detail, but the game itself is an absolute chore to play. This is going to sound like skill issue but I'm not having fun with hunting whatsoever - I'm 15 hours in and have been given little opportunity to learn from my mistakes and grow as a hunter.

The gameplay loop itself is FAR too unforgiving to a new player. I find myself constantly struggling with the controls and losing game because of it (accidentally pressing the wrong number key and having to wait 3 seconds for the character to pull out his bloody binocs before I can tell him to switch to his gun instead while my prey escapes, accidentally pressing the whistle button and scaring all the animals away because some twat thought it was a good idea to bind it next to the prone button, etc.) The fact that you can track an animal for half an hour only to bugger up when trying to take your shot is part of the game I really like because it's realistic to the act of hunting; you don't get second chances, you don't get quicksaves, and that authenticity is something I admire. But in terms of a game where the main draw is hunting, not having better tutorialisation or hell, an easier mode, is completely absurd to me. I KNOW losing hunts is my fault, but when I'm expected to take HOURS to try and get another opportunity to nab something, only to fail yet again from my inexperience, it feels like a gross waste of my time, and I literally learn nothing from it.

If the game had done a better job at introducing the aspect of hunting to me rather than dropping 6000 codex tutorials in one go and saying "alright, that's all you need to know, you should be a master now", then I'd be a lot more confident in my abilities. And while I respect that it doesn't hold your hand or baby you, I paid money for this, and I don't have hundreds of hours spare to "git gud". Not that I want every animal to freeze in place until I take a shot, mind you, I just want a fairer balance and at the very least more transparency from its mechanics (it literally doesn't properly teach you about bullet travel distances, bullet trajectory, bullet types or tools' radius usage.) It also locks a basic aiming tutorial behind DLC in Revontuli Coast - a far easier map than Hirschfelden, might I add - not to mention a WEALTH of basic quality of life improvements behind DLC too. Hope you like not having cars or tents.

IDK. I know my gameplay is my fault but for the game to not accompany me or help me learn in the slightest really frustrates me. I WANT to love this game but it just refuses to let me in. The menu and UI is dogsh!t and confusing too btw. Incredible sound design, beautifully realised environments, fantastic immersion, but a steep-ass learning curve that demands way too much time and effort from the player without putting in the effort to teach them its mechanics first. The dedication to realism is admirable but it makes actually playing the game and trying to grow an absolute slog.

Skill issue, yeah. But you know whose job it is to teach me how to play?
Nice change up from the usual games I play. This one takes time to obtain the skill, like most games, but there's a lot of ground to cover. Would recommend 10/10

This game in it's base state is nearly unplayable. Just imagine if Witcher 3 sold without horses and only a few worthless swords, then offered the horses and swords only as DLC.  That is the philosophy of Expansive Worlds. I haven't played it, but from what I understand, EW's other game is the same design. Go ahead and buy this on sale for $2.99 as I did if you want, but don't expect to have any fun what so ever without dropping at least $29 more on DLC, because the game is entirely incomplete as it is and you borderline NEED to by DLC in order to have any chance at all.  The majority of the DLC is overpriced to the max, and should be included in the base game.
All that said, the game is ok, once you buy all the quads and tents and tree stands that you need to even make the game playable. Just an OK game made by a really greedy team that is strictly pay to win.  I can't recommend anyone buy any games from EW.

[b]My Overall Opinion:[/b]

theHunter Call Of The Wild is a interesting, realistic, and immersive, thrilling experience, I personally didn't enjoy this game because it takes forever to actually get a animal, you have to sit there and wait for the animals, it's a very realistic game, it's pretty similar to real life, but it really wasn't for me. 

I'm sure the developers have put much work into this game to get it the way it is and I'm impressed with the beautiful landscape and the immersive feeling, but overall It takes a lot of patience and I don't have much patience, I don't really know what I was thinking but I thought it would be different than the way it is, it's still a cool game for those who enjoy hunting and for those that have patience.


[b]Downsides:[/b]

It takes a ton of patience and when you are somebody that doesn't have much patience for these type of things it gets hard to enjoy the game for what it is, because I could go outside and hunt and I don't think there would be much of a difference compared to this game.

This is perhaps the best example of 'Games as a Service' as I've seen. The original game released years ago but rather than pump out full priced sequels there is a steady diet of micro DLC and constant fixes and tweaks by the devs. Base game gear and maps are already varied and offer plenty of game play. There is no requirement for any of the DLC, and it is packaged in bite sized bits to allow players to mix and match whatever catches their fancy. 
DLC itself can break the base game progression a bit. The game gates off equipment behind levels and huge sums of money for new guns and gear. DLC gear appears for free in the store, meaning that you can simply ignore the game's intent of gating your progression. This is fine since it's not really a relevant part of the experience. 
Graphically this game is jaw dropping. Up close vegetation loses it's 3-D but zooming back to look at the landscape as a whole is like looking at a postcard. Lighting effects are astounding and a light morning fog with the low hanging sun sending rays of light look like it belongs in a Nat Geo documentary. Even the full moon gets enormous detail despite the accelerated time in game making it rush across the sky. There is an in-game camera and one could absolutely use this as a nature photography simulator without ever killing an animal. Sound is likewise very good, although I suggest headphones as the non-hunters in your house will probably not appreciate the sound of a dying rabbit blaring out of a bedroom. 
This is a sim, not so much a 'game'. There are story missions and trophy scoring systems, but there is no 'win' or 'lose' in COTW. It is in your best interest to hunt ethically and take well aimed shots not only for better scoring but more to save the half hour or so tracking down a barely wounded animal. This is an extremely SLOW title that will see you creeping along at a snail's pace for long stalks. And like real life sometimes spend all that time and still spook off your prey without getting to take a shot. If you require immediate gratification, this is not your game. If you are willing to invest significant amounts of time to get perhaps a single shot on a trophy, willing to let a dozen lesser beasts walk by to hopefully see the big boy- then COTW is your game. 
Hunting types are well represented including rifles, handguns, bows, and shotguns. Additionally shotguns can be loaded with buckshot and slugs for big game. Bows come in traditional, recurve, and compound as well as a crossbow. DLC can expand hunting hours to take full advantage of the 24hour day/night cycle in COTW by adding night vision. 
More than just weapon types, COTW lets you to spot and stalk, or set up treestands and tripods. Waterfowling is completely different than big game hunting and turkey hunting is it's own challenge. There is tremendous variety to be had and given the slow pace of the game- you can keep things fresh easily. 
Animals follow a realistic daily migration going from resting zones to feeding to drinking at specific times. The player can find these locations and pick a time where game can be expected. However over-hunting an area will erase these zones and they respawn randomly elsewhere requiring finding again- so controlling hunting pressure is a key part of successfully harvesting trophy animals. It's relatively easy to just walk around and stumble across game, but careful scouting to find the best among the herd will eventually lead to better spawns overall. 
The game's economy is fairly brutal without DLC adding items to the shop for free. Ammo can cost more than $1000 for ten rounds and guns and gear like treestands and waterfowl blinds cost tens of thousands of dollars each. COTW needs to knock a zero off their economy to reflect something remotely close to reality. 
There is a leveling system with skills and perk trees. Perks are broken down to weapon types but often affect all weapon types which is a bit obtuse. For example a perk to reduce recoil is found in the shotgun perk tree but affects all weapon types equally. 
Including DLC, there is plenty here for gun and hunting nerds. Maps and exotic species around the world, a range of gun types and calibers, various technologies and hunting techniques leave the player spoiled for choice. Much like real life, there can be real little practical difference between things like rifle calibers, making for a bit of an illusion of choice. Essentially the .308, 7mm, 30-06, 7.62mm and 270 win rifles are functionally identical. But gun nerds will argue endlessly which is the 'best' of the bunch so the game gives you the option.  
Animals react realistically with gunshots sending everyone bolting immediately while bow shots may allow for follow up or missed shots to not spook the herd. Wind direction, the use of cover scent or attractants will affect how close animals will come before spooking. COTW does sacrifice the realism of bag limits or specific game licenses for the sake of being more entertaining. You can hunt any animal day or night, shoot birds on the water, or simply blast an entire herd of something rather than the usual single big game animal most licenses allow. There are no off limits animals in COTW, if you can 'spot' it then you can blast it legally. 
COTW can be a relaxing walking simulator, camping simulator, photography sim, target shooting sim, and of course actual hunting sim. You could simply host a multi-player camping trip with friends with COTW. Go ride ATVs together. COTW provides huge open maps and lets you just wander around them. 
The hunting might be optional but it's very good. As a life long hunter in real life, this is about as close as it gets from a chair. I use the same tactics and approach maps the same as in real life. That is high praise for a hunting sim. The devs did an excellent job of recreating real life hunting in a video game, but with the benefit of not having to pull ticks off after hunting in New England.

In not a hunter irl and had no idea i would enjoy this game so much. There is to the perfect mix between the footprints, sounds and weapons being realistic but still accessible. My PC has  10th gen I3 and  GTX 1650 and ran this game at ultra settings maintaining 60 fps (which i was very impressed by). After about 15 hours on the base game reserves i choose to purchase the Tiage map (the snowy one) since then i have found the game to be far more enjoyable as each reserve introduces new animals and missions to explore.

In conclusion i would recommend this game to anyone who is even slightly interested as you have no idea how deep the rabbit hole goes and how calming, intense and rewarding the experience of shooting animals made of pixels can be.

cotw is one of those games that can really only be enjoyed by a specific types of people. so if you’re not a patient person, ignore this review and the game altogether.

lets start from the beginning of what would be your experience in this game. the ui is pretty straightforward. you can start a new game, continue your save, hop on multiplayer, change your settings, select a reserve, buy dlcs and leave the game. everyone starts by changing their settings, so let’s talk about that first. you can adjust quite a few things in this game, the visuals, the gameplay, the interface, the audio, hell you can even change your red dot sight reticle. and yet the settings are simple and every setting comes with a brief explanation of what it is. 

start a new game, and you’ll find yourself in the very first reserve of the two you have access to as a new player, layton lakes or hirschfelden. i recommend you start on layton lakes since hirschfelden is quite challenging to hunt on. upon spawning in, you’ll find yourself in the coast of a pretty big map, and yatsume that point you cant help but notice the graphics. 

the graphics in this game are amazing, and the maps are beautifully crafted too. every reserve in the game is based on a real life region, although they’re not existing reserves. one thing that may surprise you (it definitely surprised me) is the optimization. my computer isn’t exactly amazing (i have an almost 4 years old 1050 ti, 16gb of ram, and a i7-4770 cpu) and yet the game ran very well even on the highest graphic setting. this is in big part thanks to what i think is an awesome feature of the game, AMD FSR. it improves the games frames a fucking ton while making the image still perfectly fine. after looking around a bit you may notice a deer in front of you. this is the tutorial deer, and trust me, the animals won’t be this easy to find.

the animal models look amazing on most species. i do wish they reworked the jackals, for example, but that’s just an exception. animals in this game come with many different fur/plumage/scale types which adds to the variety of what you could find. one really cool thing about this game is that the animals that are on your map will always be on it until you kill them, and they’ll respawn as an animal of the same species and same sex. for example, if you kill a female whitetail deer a female whitetail deer will respawn. you take aim at the deer and you’re supposed to aim for the animals vital organs, but the tutorial doesn’t tell you where the lungs are (behind the front shoulder blade of the animal). so a lot of people just shoot the deer’s head out of fps experience, and the deer runs off. stuff like the rifle shot and the bolting has really good animation and sound behind it. the animations that this game has for the animals are really nice and very realistic. you’ll find a bunch of bugs regarding them every now and then but more than ruining the experience it’s pretty funny to see. 

tracking in this game is very simplified compared to real life. tracks and blood trails are very highlighted and easy to see, as well as the animal’s corpse. once you confirm your trophy you get to the harvest menu, which tells you the animals fur type, trophy score, medal of the animal and each shot you took at it before it died. you can toggle x rays vision to see the animal’s anatomy in this screen and it’s pretty accurate to real life anatomy. the trophy score will determine a rating: none, bronze, silver, gold, and diamond. there’s a special rating, the great one, which is incredibly rare to find and doesn’t depend on trophy score. for those that do depend on it, each species has a different amount of minimum score to get to that medal. the medal can go down by one level if you mess up what’s known as the harvest check: using proper ammo for the animal, shooting the animal less than two times, ruining the animal’s trophy organ (99% of the time it’s their skull) and hitting a vital organ, which can be the brain, heart, lungs and liver. when hunting ducks and rabbits there’s no need to hit vital organs however. 

this game requires a lot of patience once you’re done with the tutorial and hunting some animals. if you keep running thinking the animals are stupid, you’ll just make them all flee. if you’re not careful, this game can be quite frustrating to play, but when you do get rewards like some diamond trophies it feels amazing. speaking of trophies, you can taxidermy these trophies and exhibit them at one of three trophy lodges, two of which are locked behind dlc. there are a lot of weapons in this game: rifles, bows, shotguns, handguns, even a goddamn muzzleloader. however, 90% of these are locked behind dlc. there are lots of reserves, but only two come with the base game. some awesome utilities like tents that allow you to fast travel anywhere you place them or tripods that give you an elevated position, keep you concealed, etc. that are locked behind dlc. there’s a dog that can help you track animals by smelling their blood that is locked behind dlc. you may be noticing a pattern here. 

yeah this game has a ton of content locked behind dlcs. it’s nice that they go on sale often but it’s kind of ridiculous. 

the game seems to crash a lot. this isn’t just me, it’s a lot of people that are having this problem. it’s not too annoying but it can definitely fuck you over sometimes.

i mentioned multiplayer earlier. it’s really cool that you can play in maps you dont own in multiplayer, but there’s quite a few issues with it: lag, modders, etc. 

overall you should absolutely pick this game up if it’s on sale, and may as well pick a few dlcs with it. i managed to get a solid combo during black friday for 20€, which is the usual price for just the base game.

So it says I have played 270 hrs since my last review in which I gave this a thumbs down. To be quik about it, over time they have fixed most of the real issues. Not happy with the online stuff but at the same time not unhappy either as it turned out to be more of a nothingburger. For more info on that read all the old review stuff below. The game is also still a little "stick it to ya" with the DLCs but its not too bad. The reserves themselves are worth the money. Its the rest of the DLCs that are questionable. BUt as far as game play goes, its a decent solid, good looking game without too many issues. It is by far the best hunting game out there including the most recent addition which I will leave unnamed since I am changing this review to a thumbs up.

For old review read below. So I like to keep up on this game, even go shoot something occasionally. Thought I would update my review. Basically nothing below really has changed much and things have gotten worse. So they slowly started introducing or migrating over to an online gaming system. No one is happy about this. And today, the day before April Fools day, they force everyone on steam to download a 24gb in store dlc. So it is really apparent where this game is heading, basically a privately owned version of their classic online game, but in the worse way possible. They talked up the online thing as if it was going to make the gaming better with competitive missions or competitions. Then the very next thing they do is an in game dlc store. I think the writing is on the wall on where they are going with this. Dont buy unless you are willing to put up with all the flaws and coming soon to a monitor near you, the money train-drain.

There needs to be a "MEH" catagory to the rating.

Graphics ok, but some "glitches".
Sound is ok but some "glitches"

Basically if you are into playing this in single player and you don't mind animals all looking identical within a species. Then I would recondmend it as it is an ok hunting platform at the price point and with additional DLC's (see below) buying the ones you like, I would then recommend this game.

If you want to play this game with friends I would advise you and friends get the hunter "classic" MP game with a year subscription. You will be VASTLY happier in what you can do MP wise with creating hunts ect than what you can do currently in this title. And I don't think they are intent on making the MP of this game better or more like thier "classic" title.

DLC's and the future: As just noted, I don't think they intend to improve the MP aspect of this game much. At least nowhere near what they should and no where near the "classic" version of this game.
Other than that , expect a plethora of .99 to 4.99 DLC content. They started with the tent/blind DLC and it will go on. Birds, other animals , more weapons will all be added and it looks like at a piecemeal price point (items sold individually) which is good for those that want to pick and choose what they hunt and hunt with. But I am sure there are folks who will want and may get bundles.

Since I bought this specifically to play MP and my grading is two different grades I have to go with my MP score/reason. And just cannot recommend this title.

dont waste your time with this game, spent thousands of hours on it between console and pc and my honest view is that this game has had so many changes come to the game for the better that instead of being apart of the base game are instead DLC, such ATV's, Tents, Dogs, hunting equipment such as stand/tripods and EVERY SINGLE HUNTING RESERVE except layton lake and hirschfelden (7/10 maps imo) are all payed DLC. 75% of real hunting equipment IRL for hunting water fowl are payed DLC aswell, most common effective hunting calibers arent even in the base game such as 6.5, 30-06, .300win, 7mm, unless you pay for the gun packs which are all separate instead of a bundle of course. 

The hunting experience of the game is a joke too, most of it just boils down to sprinting around everywhere with my ar-15 getting withing 200yd and just blasting as many deer as i can in order to get higher level deer to spawn, and because the AI is so borked they dont even care im shooting at them and will eventually walk back to that same spot were i shot them 3 minutes later. and alot of the time  higher level deer like "diamonds" spawn and sometimes they will just run out of bounds de-spawning themselves or just not allowing you to get them, rarely if you kill an taxidermy animals they just wont count as trophy's and wont be mountable but ive had this happen, sill gun and arrow physics are pretty fun like for instance my 450gr broadhead being able to travel through an entire cape buffalo length wise lmao

overall the lighting and weather of the game is what sells it but the overall graphics are a 6/10 but there not nearly as bad as say a game like the hunter classic, but for a game that came out in 2017 is expect better. and the story is terribly boring, you play as a no name hunter came to get as many diamond trophies as you can and overall the game is just chasing dialouge no real events, the most fun story i played was the "vurhonga savannah" cause i thought the characters *even though you never see faces* were interesting


Overall if you want to play a hunting game that has good hunting mechanics and good animal behavior AI, aswell as a wide variety of the most commonly used hunting calibers and an experience with good graphics aswell as story. there are better options that dont cost nearly as much money as buying this game and all its DLC. i recommend "way of the hunter" its a 8/10 experience in my opinion that is simply superior to the experience i had in the hunter COTW. this games trophy hunting and animal slaughtering with my friends will always hold a special place in my heart

This game is often ludicrously good looking, has a very fun and simple gameplay loop, and is generally just a chill nice time traipsing through the woods while testing your hunting abilities.

But I cannot really fully recommend this due to major issues with the audio. The spatialisation is just busted, the direction which you hear stuff is frequently completely wrong, sometimes 180 degrees wrong. In a game with otherwise very nice sound design and foley this is a huge shame and it causes real problems in gameplay. The game does have a visual indicator thing that shows where sounds are coming from, and this is basically essential otherwise you would end up looking in the wrong direction when you hear an animal. It's especially annoying with the dog's barking when they're tracking an animal, I generally have to bring up the GPS map thing to see where he actually is.

It seems like these this issue with audio spatialisation has been reported for many years now and it hasn't been fixed, this really isn't great.

It's mostly solid otherwise though one bug that keeps happening for me is the weapon and all gear seemingly disappearing from my hands when I make certain inputs in fast sequence, and I have to go into the inventory to unequip/equip to bring it all back so I can use a gun etc. If this happens at a critical moment as an animal is passing by it kind of kills my enthusiasm for the game tbh.

Hopefully this stuff gets sorted sooner rather than later because I really like the game and would like to play more.

--- UPDATE: Dec 12, 2023 ---

I wanted to update my review. Notably, I still recommend the game if you are interested in a hunting simulator. I would, however, advise abstaining from the majority of the DLC that has been released outside of maps really. I have almost all DLC and they just dropped another collection of 5 or 6 "purely cosmetic" DLCs at $2,99USD a piece. The game just isn't worth the amount of money they charge for it anymore. Buy it on sale, get the maps, maybe a gun pack that you like, but otherwise it is an Arcade hunting game mostly.

I'm sure their competition will fall into the same boat as CotW has, but this DLC abuse has turned me away from the product now. I choose to play their biggest competitor as it is a more accurate simulation and currently has a much more reasonable price tag for new players interested in a challenging simulation.

TLDR; I still recommend the game, but don't waste your money on any of the cash grab DLCs that add zero to the game. There is no point in cosmetics for things you don't actually see in the game 99% of the time. Make educated financial decisions.

As an avid hunter, I would recommend this game. I am very much enjoying the scenery as well as the realistic four-wheeling around the reservation. The gun recoil, the slight delay for animal response due to sound travel, and just the peace and quiet sitting alone out in the middle of nowhere literally for hours is realistic as well. Yes I've sat for an hour or so on this game and taken a nap to wake up 30 yards from an 8 point buck. My only disappointment/request would be fixed position gun support. If I'm in a blind or prone, I would have my rifle resting on a bag rest or bi-pod/shooting stick and won't have any barrel motion. This game, like hunting itself, does not serve up trophies. you have to hunt for them. I like it.

My boyfriend introduced me to this game and I got hooked pretty quick thanks to hunting games being my shameless pleasure games. It gives me the same enjoyment I had when I was playing Cabela's Big Game Hunter on the first family PC.

Update December 2023

The audio in this game has been a problem since day one and the devs have done nothing to fix it. They just ignore it and act like it doesn’t exist. I remember asking them about it on a live stream in 2017 and they kicked me out right away. Six years later, it’s still a mess. I played the game again after a long time and it was so obvious that the audio was broken.

I hunted an animal and let the dog track it down. I was standing a few meters away from the dog and I turned 90 degrees to the left or right. The dog would be on my left side, but I would hear it from the right side, and vice versa. It’s not my sound setup, I checked the Windows audio test and made sure the left and right channels were correct.

I tried this on three other machines, including a Steam deck, and the same problem was there. I used different headphones and speakers, like Airpods, Sennheiser HD280s, Sennheiser PXC550, some old Skullcandy headset, and my Studio Edifier monitors.

There is no doubt that the sound engine is still faulty. You will hear animals as if they are right next to you, but they are actually far away. You will hear footsteps that you think are on your left side, but they are actually on your right side, and you will scare away the animal when you look.

The devs will not fix it, they don’t admit that it’s an issue, and I’m sure that it’s too hard for them to fix because of their lacklustre development skills. The game is seven years old and it still can’t run on high or ultra settings and get more than 100 fps on a 3090 TI. That shows that they only care about making new content and fixing minor bugs.

Update (April 2022)
DO NOT BUY THIS GAME!
Even when it's on sale, why?
Developers do NOT listen, they add useless updates that just wastes space and cater to the Console version. They DO NOT FIX BUGS, MAJOR GAME BREAKING BUGS.

DLC keeps getting priority over bugs that are FIVE YEARS OLD STILL!
Now they have added an INTERNAL DLC STORE that is 18Gigs, which provides ZERO benefit for Steam Customers, PROVING where their interests are content over quality.

If you decide to ignore this and BUY the game, you will 90% have a chance of crashing after you waited HOURS for your massive download. YES you download DLC that you do NOT OWN to inflate your game folder. The devs do NOT care.

Look at the REPLY from the devs below from 2 years ago. They said "several of those bugs should be addressed now" IT'S A LIE! Almost ALL of those BUGS are still there and haven't been fixed in FIVE YEARS!

Dev below: " i might not fully agree to your statement about DLC since the team working on bugs not necessarily work on expansions and vice verca."

THAT IS BULLSHAAIT! If that was true, BIG fixes would have come down WITH DLC, but all that is being released is MORE DLC and ZERO BUG FIXES!

AGAIN, DO NOT BUY THIS GAME !!!

Below is my original review, which I would have removed, but I still don't recommend this game and my opinion stands. DLC is of higher priority than bugs and other issues. The map issues have been removed, which is a better experience. But wow is there still a lot of issues present. One complete game breaker is how the audio completely falls over itself. I just hear my own footsteps and anything in like a 5 meter radius from me. I have to restart the game to fix it. Animals can still teleport vast distances, now to even more impossible locations. I'm sad that I have to now just uninstall it and not bother to try again, Avalanche got my money, I guess that matters more... at least people can get it on sale now and not lose too much if they are willing to take a chance on this game. ah well 🤷‍♂️

I was an early bird to this game, and bought it in the first week.
Played it for many hours as  you can see, but there was so many bugs from the beginning and the game was costly at the time.  

After nearly 3 years now, this game still has the same bugs:
-Opening the map is slow as hell. How can they STILL not fix this?!?!
-The map loads POI's, Needzones, etc slower than Google Maps on an smoke signal network...
-The Map NEVER remembers the last position it was closed at.
-Map mission zones needs "movement" to display (zoom or move map).
-Maps on Multiplayer take nearly 3 seconds to open....WTF>?!?
-Animals still teleport vast distances or through mountains.
-Animals still do the Moonwalk against a tree non-stop
-Animal transitions are still janky as hell and has never been smooth
-Binoculars opened and then fast travelling STILL keeps the binocular HUD on screen.

There is so many more bugs, and they JUST DON'T get fixed...
I buy every DLC, and hope the added patch would fix issues, but Expansive worlds are pretending now that they are like EA, and don't give a 💩, and rather push out content, instead of squashing bugs.

I felt especially frustrated now, because they add more and more bugs with their features, which costs me Diamonds and this game already cost so much in patience. 

The developers just ignore the playerbase and continues pushing out features, and ignores fixes.

I'm done, I recommend NOT buying this game, even patient people will get impatient with this mess now...

I have 117 hours in this game (all on Steam Deck), but it has been many months since I have played. I opened the game a couple of months ago and found that I could not get a playable frame rate and good-enough graphics at the same time, which was weird, because I did not have any problems before, so I forgot about the game again for a while. I now have the Steam Deck OLED, which has slightly better all round performance, and find that the situation has not changed.

When I used to play, I tried to do so as "authentically" as possible - no HUD, no glowing tracks etc, no assists, no ATV (which are all cheating), and limited fast travel, and I had a great time. I finished the entirety of Yukon Valley, maybe half of all Rancho content, maybe half of Cuatro Colinas content, and bits of other maps, using 3 weapons packs, the bloodhound, and the tents DLC. I never got around to playing the Medved DLC that I bought, but I may do so if the game runs better some day.

The game nails the atmosphere of certain locations, though not necessarily on every part of each map, and not in all weathers. I have spent a lot of time in Spain in real life, and Quatro Colinas has areas and views that are distinctly evocative of parts of Spain.

It is annoying that you have to download the entire new DLC map when one is released, whether you will buy it or not, which really eats away memory card space (about 10GB per map, which is not nothing). The justification is that you can play all maps for free on other peoples' servers, but I would rather have the 50GB+ of disk space from the 5+ maps that don’t interest me at all.

The “plot” of each area is mostly just ways to try to justify gunning down the various species in the name of “conservation” or “population control”; in reality, the best technique is to re-establish top predators (typically having been wiped out by hunting), not to kill them. And the other kind of mission story tends to be improving facilities for the rich hunters who pay to hunt in the area, though you never see them.

Notably, the free trophy lodge that they added a few months ago is absolutely atrocious, apart from the view. I wish I could get a refund for it. I just thought I'd mention that.
The African trophy lodge is OK but I would wait until you have a good number of actually-worth-displaying trophies before paying for a trophy lodge, or you will end up with mostly-empty rooms.

It's obviously not a perfect simulation, but it's a good tracking and shooting game, and a great price when on sale. Now fix it for the Steam Deck please!

My absolute Favourite game to play.  Amazing graphics almost feels like real hunting.  You sure learn a lot about weapons. Have spent countless hours playing on my Xbox now I am playing on the PC. So much fun to start all over again.

222.2 hours, as good a time as any to give my thoughts on this title. (I have more than this if consoles are included)

First and foremost! This game is not for everyone. I love it because guns and hunting are 2 thing I enjoy conceptually and I love the slow pace of this game. If that doesn't sound like something you can enjoy, this game probably won't peak your interests.

This has a lot to love. The story (although sometimes drawn out) is oddly cozy and warm feeling with the wardens of each reserve providing a great window into the history of the places you hunt in. I found myself really looking forward to completing missions to hear what the Warden had to say to me next and what hunt was next on the agenda and that's about as much praise as I can give any story.

The game play is smooth and very satisfying. All of the guns sound amazing and impactful with recoil that really gives a punch to every shot. The animal behaviour although a tad basic, does the job of fooling you into believing that you are hunting an animal, not just an AI. All animals have different levels of hearing, sight, and smell which changes how you need to approach certain hunts. And I can't not mention the visuals. The game is demanding on hardware but beautiful to look on every single reserve.

Some cons of the game: max view distance is only 400M so no REALLY long range shots but the game is designed in such a way that you don't really want more than that distance anyway. Animals can become very predictable after some time. The game has A LOT of paid DLC which can turn people off it. I will defend that though as although I hate paid DLC's, every DLC I have bought has felt well worth the price.

Tip if you are planning on getting the game: make sure you have the ATV DLC and the tents DLC. They will make life a hell of a lot easier for you.

In conclusion: I love this game. I really think this is 1 of if not THE best hunting experience you can have in a video game. I've played it for hundreds of hours and I'll play it for hundreds more. I hope you find the same enjoyment I did.

Great way to lose yourself for while. And you can shoot stuff, or not. Beautiful scenery and SFX.

I enjoy the ambient sounds and realistic elements of the game. However, what I find challenging is the user interface, especially for beginners like myself. Accessing certain menus, such as buying items, managing storage, navigating to the inventory, and configuring equipment, can be cumbersome. One aspect I find frustrating is the process of setting up items in the inventory.

Regarding the DLC for dogs, it would be beneficial to have an option for the dog to follow by simply right-clicking. This feature could greatly enhance the overall experience. Another issue I encountered is when playing multiplayer with friends. Sometimes, my friends want to mark a point on the map, and it would be helpful if there were a cooperative mode or a feature that allows everyone to see each other's marks. The current method of marking spots can be challenging, as the mark occasionally goes far away, and the arrow effect seems subpar. Additionally, inviting players doesn't seamlessly integrate into the game.

On a positive note, I appreciate the extensive information provided about animals and the game's environmental effects, such as weather changes and time progression. The diverse scenarios and areas, along with the well-designed maps, make the game captivating, and I can easily spend hours immersed in it.

One suggestion for improvement would be to diversify the blood trails, as they currently appear repetitive. Despite these issues, I believe it's a fantastic game that I would recommend. Just be cautious about the time spent in one sitting—starting at night might lead to witnessing the morning sunrise before you realize it!
