My son is too scared of the "Skibidi Toilet" to start potty training

My son is three years old, and we've been trying to potty train him for a while now. Unfortunately, we've hit a major roadblock - his fear of the "skibidi toilet" You might be wondering what a "skibidi toilet" is, and honestly, I had no idea either until we encountered it. Fron what I've gathered, "skibidi toilet" is basically a new genre of youtube video about evil singing toilets. Basically think zombies but instead they're toilets that sing in your face. I was fine to let my son watch the videos at first, as they seemed innocent enough and fairly harmless, but they soon devolved into strange post apocalyptic material with grotesque toilets fighting in a war against mankind, so I finally intervened and cut him off. I thought that was the end of it, he can't watch the videos anymore so theres nothing to be afraid of. Well, I was wrong. This has since turned into a complete nightmare for us at home. We recently started potty training and he refuses to use the toilet now due to skibidi toilet. Whenever we try to put him on it he screams and refuses to go anywhere near it. We've tried explaining that skibidi toilet isnt real and our toilet is completely safe, but it seems like it's too overwhelming for him. We even let him decorate it with stickers, hoping it would make him less afraid, but no luck so far. It utterly breaks my heart to see him so anxious about such a simple thing that every child goes through. I'm not sure how to proceed from here. Should we give him more time and hope that he warms to the toilet, or is it better to try a completely different approach? I know every child is different, but has anyone else experienced something similar? How did you deal with skibidi toilet in your household, if you encountered it

If you are satisfied with occasionally hopping on and shooting some animals then this game is for you. If you are looking for an in depth simulation hunting game well, there are some short-comings. Overall rating 8/10

1st complaint is that alot of the DLC is lame. The ATV is absolutely necessary unless you want to spend a thousand hours travelling the maps. 

Another thing to be aware of is the only weapon customization are the scopes and ammo. For shooting small animals like ducks and rabbits you need a class 1 specific ammo which takes about 50 hours killing stuff to level up your weapon level to be able to purchase this ammo. As for the different scopes you need to spend 50 hours leveling up your weapons to be able to purchase the different scopes as well. 

Not a huge deal, but I shot one of the birds in the game and it gave me the animation of it falling but it just disappears. There is no harvest for it. 

Besides the time dedication for the different perks, scopes, and other equipment. So far the game has been pretty fun. If the above complaints don't bother you then Buy this game. Be a man.

Homemade Landjäger Sausage

Ingredients:
- 500 g beef
- 500 g pork
- 20 g curing salt (nitrite curing salt)
- 5 g coarse ground pepper
- 5 g sweet paprika
- 3 g garlic powder
- 2 g ginger powder
- 2 g dried marjoram
- 1 g ground coriander
- 1 g grated nutmeg
- 1 g ground cardamom
- Pork casings for stuffing
- Kitchen twine

Instructions:
1. Cut the beef and pork into small pieces and pass them through a meat grinder with a coarse plate.
2. Place the ground meat in a large bowl and add all the spices (curing salt, pepper, paprika, garlic powder, ginger powder, marjoram, coriander, nutmeg, and cardamom). Mix well until the spices are evenly distributed.
3. Cover the meat mixture and let it rest in the refrigerator for at least 24 hours to allow the flavors to develop.
4. Thoroughly clean the pork casings and soak them in cold water to soften.
5. Remove the meat mixture from the refrigerator and knead it again to ensure proper blending.
6. Stuff the meat mixture into the prepared pork casings, ensuring there are no air pockets and that the casings are evenly filled.
7. Cut the filled casings into approximately 10 cm long pieces and tie the ends with kitchen twine.
8. Hang the Landjäger sausages in a cool place to dry for about 2-3 weeks. The ideal temperature is around 15-18 degrees Celsius.
9. After the drying period, the Landjäger sausages are ready to be consumed. They can be enjoyed raw or lightly pan-fried.

Note: When making sausage, it is important to maintain proper hygiene. Ensure all utensils are thoroughly cleaned, and use fresh meat. It is also recommended to familiarize yourself with basic sausage-making principles and consider employing specific sausage-making techniques.

For myself I really enjoy the game. It can be quite challenging starting out and even once you have experience certain animals are still difficult to get close enough to down. A game worth playing is one that remains challenging in my opinion. I don't particularly care for the boat-load of weapons available but different weapons do provide a different challenge level if you want to push yourself further. The animals can also be a bit buggy at times, allowing for some easy mass slaughtering if you come across a situation like I did where there was a section of river all the animals were frozen on. Even once shot the animals just stood there until they died. I enjoy the fact that you have to be patient and wait for a good shot otherwise you may lose the animal entirely or have to chase it halfway across the map, not a fun thing to do trust me :D. Not all animals react like this, pigs for instance are spot on. They often very quickly return to an area or stop running a lot faster then other species. In real life this is exactly the way they are, they return to a feed spot even if one of their group is freshly killed on the ground. I really like the tracking dog even though he bugs out sometimes. There is a lot to like about this game and very few inconveniences in my opinion. I highly recommend playing with a friend! Communicating back and forth about what you are currently stalking is a lot of fun and of course there is the bragging rights when you find the 'Big One'.

Wasn't sure I'd like it, but bought it on super-sale. I love it. I've played 35 hours in less than a week and bought almost all the DLC (also on sale). It's definitely not your typical FPS. It requires PATIENCE; moving slow across wide and far distances so you don't scare game, often only getting one shot on your target before the herd runs, etc. It took some adjustment for me, but I got there. Now it's relaxing, almost meditative. Taking things slowly without any rush, exploring beautiful natural areas, it's amazing. To new players: you may not see any animals at first, but they're there - it just takes some player adaptation to a new way of playing. Don't give up after just a few hours. Keep going and you'll love the game, too.

Hunter provides a surprising progression system in not only in that various items unlock as you hunt along, but also qualitatively as you learn animal anatomy and hone in on your ability to move and shoot in various conditions. The sandbox-esque atmosphere allows you the ability to make your own fun however you feel. Go on an absolute genocidal spree with your friends, or restrict yourself to bag limits and compare your best scored harvests. Also, each map provides a little bit of story which incentivizes exploration as well as bagging new animals. Some can get a bit tedious and repetitive, but do allow for a quick change of pace and an opportunity to work on a new approach to hunting if you start to grow a bit tired of freeroaming.

What I expected: Basic hunting game where I can shoot random deer that all look the same.

What I got: 
- Fly higher than SpaceX by ramming into my friend with the 4X4 and get thrown into space.
- Cruising through the savanna and literally die because a water buffalo  came running through the tall grass and ran me over.
- Spend hours and hours to get a Great One fallow deer, and in the process got some nice albino, melanistic and piebald fallow deer.
- Try to get a diamond tier Banteng in Emerald Coast map but because of lack of patience I shoot it from 350m away, miss his vital organs and thus ruining the diamond ranking.
- Get killed by a group of wolves in Medved Taiga, my friend kills all of them and instantly becomes rich.
- Run after bunnies in Te Awaroa, literally killed the whole population by blasting them all with my shotgun, ended up with a nice albino European Rabbit.
-Join multiplayer hosted maps to steal their diamond ranked goat.
- Get diamond ranked Mule Deer stolen by flying cheater that comes in faster than a F16 jet.

Not sure what you guys are trying to accomplish with this game, But I really don't care for background characters overtly talking 24/7 when I'm actually trying to hunt or have me run around and do pointless tasks that have nothing to do with hunting. 102 minutes in and I'm finding myself annoyed with the "Guide" or whatever the person constantly talking is supposed to be.
Under the impression this was a hunting game not a game where I gotta listen to a dude blab about his life and how the reserve is against him turning it into a extreme sports resort or whatever the heck he's going on about. We trying to make a hunting game here or a story mode guys? Cause I could care less about what a unseen character has going on in their lives. I'm here to hunt an bag some animals. Not set up fliers for poisoned water or fetch rock climbing gear.

As someone who was a major fan of the Deer Hunter game series when they were first released back in the late 90s, Call of the Wild feels like the spiritual successor to Deer Hunter. From tracking, using lures, utilizing the terrain to your advantage to sneak up on animals, to finally getting into position setting up the chance to take that perfect shot. It is an incredible experience, especially when all that work pays off and you drop the animal you were stalking in one shot.

Breathtaking scenery and visuals help draw you into the game, and combined with the game mechanics make this feel like a high end hunting simulator.

The only thing that seems off about the game is the animal AI. Had a female moose walk up approximately 10 feet in front of me while I was crouched before it panicked and took off. Another odd occurrence is when you spook an animal and it flees, sometimes the pathfinding it takes is a little bizarre. As someone who hunts White Tail Deer in real life, I can't help but notice the pathfinding while fleeing doesn't seem entirely natural. Nevertheless, this is a minor complaint in an otherwise great game.

WARNING: PATIENCE NECESSARY

Dissappointed at my display the beauty scoffed at me and ran away. Once again I was denied my advance to become a skilled hunter. Afterwards I was so dumbstruck by my own incompetence, I seem to have unlearned the skills to use any of my tools. I was convinced this day couldnt get any worse only to find out that one of my previous advances towards an innocent pig family was looted by one of my peers. 

I have not yet decided, if I retire my hunting rod or not. 
Only the future knows

What is the point of tracking an animal if they always move faster than you?
You see poop on the ground, it says "Just Now", you sneak forward and the next poop you see is "Very Fresh" and then you move further and then it says "Fresh", but if you move faster the animal runs away, it's impossible for me to even see an animal unless it is one eating or drinking, but at that point it is so far away that I can't take the shot or I'll miss (which is honestly my problem), I move further towards it and it runs away again, repeating everything I said above.
"you have to be patient and not run around" well if I am patient the animal runs away faster than I can catch up and I dont get it either, what's the fucking point? I can't even imagine how slow you would be if you tried to track an animal while being prone.
I tried it again a few years later and I still fucking hate it. I tracked an animal for an hour and it always fled even though it was not within line of sight, the wind wasn't a problem and I was crouching. I killed two other animals on the way because it took so fucking long. And it may be realistic but how fucking long can an animal bleed for fuck's sake. Fuck this game, it's not even enjoyable for the atmosphere cause I can hear my PC blasting constantly due to the high graphics. The 10 hours it took to install it again were the worst waste of time in the whole of 2023.

Why is this 6+ year old game so expensive? The price of the base game is reasonable given its age, but in reality the base game is just a paid demo since so many features are locked away in DLC. At least sale prices bring the bundles with the essentials to a more realistic price point. I went into the game knowing this and got it on sale, but it's still scummy of the publisher.

Another big issue with the game though is that the new player experience if you're not familiar with hunting in RL is extremely poor. I bought this over the other hunting games since many reviews said that while the other was a better simulator, this was a better game even if it was a bit arcadey. That may be true once you figure out how to break the animal AI, but for a new player this is animal spook simulator. To add insult to injury, the starting ammo for your starter rifle is a poor choice for the deer you're asked to hunt right off the bat and you have to level up a few times to get actually decent ammo. The game tells you none of this, I kept shooting deer where you're supposed to (again had to look it up outside of the game since it drops you in with basically no guidance) and outside of a couple lucky shots I would just wound them and they had "very low blood loss" and would run halfway across the map with what I would assume to be a very significant wound in RL. Not impressed with the new player experience.

At least the DLC guns in the bundle are available right away, kind of progression breaking, but given how bad progression so far is I honestly don't care.

I fully recommend this game! 

While it might have its bugs here and there (Usually coursed by an update or new content - They usually get fixed), it can give you some the most satisfying moments, when you accomplish to get your hands on a trophy-worthy animal. Perhaps your shot was impressive too! 
The game isn't from 2021, but the graphics never seize to impress me. The surroundings and the way the animals behave around it really helps on making yourself emerge into the feeling of being out on a hunt. 
Play it with friends, it only gets better. Communication, tracking, guiding. With teamwork, you can bring home some of the best and most memorable trophies for your lodge!  

Although, with the multiplayer-option, there are a few points that could be up for improvement: 
- Story line mission together. The game has a campaign, but it is only available in single-player mode. Would be great if you could share that experience with your friends as well, discuss the stories as you go.    
- Non-campaign mission. Start a map, choose a handful of missions with varied difficulties perhaps (Depending on your equipment) and go get it done! 
- Hunt Club Beta overhaul. The game has a feature called "Hunt Club Beta". Those are dailies, weeklies and community missions. The community being the only one with a shared progress (Unfortunately). - Sadly, this feature has been out of order for a while. Hoping to see it re-implemented soon..

After almost 1k hours, it's safe to say I really like this game.

The base game has two maps, one of which is still in my top 5 reserves. The game has plenty of DLCs to expand the hunting experience (more maps, guns and equipment) but it's not necessary to purchase any of them in the beginning, or at all. I still have the starting rifle with me on most hunts and I still have a few missions left on the base maps.

I do recommend maybe watching a few tutorials for beginners but theHunter: Call of the Wild is a very easy game to get into. Just remember that it's a hunting simulator so stealth and patience go a long way, but you can suddenly find yourself face to face with a nice pray while just walking around.

So, I've been wiping out the animal population for 230 hours already....

Strengths of this game include:

1. HUGE maps, with many to choose from.
2. Solid graphics.
3. Randomness!!! - Encountering a super rare animal of a lifetime, with random fur patterns and randomly generated 4. horns, adds a unique touch to each find. You can save it to your house and show your friends the slaughter you accomplished. That's the number one fun factor for me.
4. Continuous development with patches and content, albeit mostly paid. For me, this is a strength because I love supporting the game rather than letting it die.

Weaknesses:
1. Mild bugs and map imperfections.
2. If you want all DLCs, you have to take out a loan.
3. The inventory management system is kind of confusing and hard to learn initially, but after a while, you'll get it.

Overall, I love it. There's no better and more sophisticated hunting game out there, with plenty of content to explore. Nothing rushes you, and you can switch off and relax after a hard day. It might be pretty boring for younger gamers, though.

I've never had any particular interest in hunting, but 2020 found me looking for a special bit of escapism somewhere, and I found it here. It's been a kind of therapy to be able to roam the absolutely gorgeous environments of Layton Lakes and  Hirschfelden. I would have been content just to treat the game as a walking simulator, but I found myself really enjoying the hunting as well. I understand now something of what real life hunters get out of the experience. There's a genuine thrill to finally bagging that quarry you've been tracking and trying to coax out for what seems like forever. (I'm looking at you, coyotes and foxes.)

It's also admittedly a flawed game missing a certain amount of polish. Many problems are smaller quality of life issues, but the big one for me is the limited animal pathfinding. Too often I've caught up to a herd stuck on a hillside going in circles, for example.

Having said that, I'd say the pros outweigh the cons enough that I'd recommend anyone give the base game a try even if only for the landscapes as I originally did. Happy Hunting!

I've been playing theHunter CotW since it's release, back when I played xbox a lot more (now I play it on PC). Well, 5 years have gone down the road, and I still play this game like it's a brand new game that I want to play every day. Some people may be wondering, why do I love it so much. Well, I'll explain. It's one game that has always been my go-to when I don't know what to play (in fact I'm about to start it up as I type this). It's one game that once you get to understanding more, you can easily learn all the anatomy of all these animals, and even more-so, when you become a good shot, it's super easy. My goal is to one day unlock every single achievement, out of respect of the fact I've been playing it this long, might as well. Another amazing thing, the graphics. Now some people may say they are a bit wonky, which I agree at times, but overall, it's amazing how these graphics are. They are absolutely stunning, my opinion. Another plus, all the different maps and animals available are insane. I can go on all day about why I love this game so much, bu I'll spare it. All in all, 100/10, one of the best games I've ever started, and to this day, 5 years later, I don't regret it at all. I even got all the DLCs, and when more come out, I plan to get them too lol. Thank you, creators, for making a game I've been wishing for since I was young, finally a dream come true.

Overall one of the best hunting simulators that I have played that encorporates multiplayer, the game runs beautifully, it does not have too many bugs or glitches and is quite real. Pros:
-Beautiful game engine
-Realistic animal behavior MOST of the time
-Animals can hear you from very very far, which makes bagging an animal even more satisfying
-Lots of weapon choices, ammo choices, calls, and bait
-The game does an excellent job of making tracking animals as easy as possible by highlighting tracks that you are following and other tracks a seperate color and showing how old poop is to inform you of the age of the tracks of the animal.
-There is a story mode and it can be fun to level up
-There is online multiplayer with friends and you can all go hunting together

Cons:
-The game is almost worthless without the DLC for ATV and Tents, these two items should have obviously been in the game from the start and not set up as DLC, without tents or ATV's it is almost impossible to get around easily and meet your friends, what is worse is you can not ride a friends ATV, you have to have your own, and Tents are essentially fast travel locations that you can put up anywhere and that anyone can travel to, you can also resupply at a tent making them invaluable.  I like to place tents where animals usually show up and then fast travel between them.
-The game does make you level up in order to unlock the calls ytou need to really start bagging animals, if you do not play story missions it will take some time before you are able to aquire these items.
-This is a hunting simulator, I have played for 45 minutes stalking and tracking to never ever even see an animal, and came up empty, if this does not sound like something you can handle maybe look at an arcade type hunting game.




Overall really good simulation game if you have time to kill, and like to relax and go slow and take your time.

theHunter: Call of the Wild is a game that has truly surprised me. As someone who never thought a hunting game could hold my interest for long, I found myself utterly engrossed in its serene and enjoyable gameplay. If you're the type of player who thrives on "run and gun" action like Call of Duty, well, this might not be your cup of tea. But for those who appreciate a slower, more methodical approach, this game offers a rewarding and relaxing experience.

Let me clarify something upfront: theHunter: Call of the Wild is not a hardcore hunting simulator like its sibling, theHunter Classic. Instead, it blends simulation elements into a gaming experience that demands your attention to its challenging learning curve. You'll need to consider factors like noise, wind direction, and more to succeed. Charging through the woods with guns a-blazing will only leave you empty-handed and frustrated. Take your time, be patient, and you'll find plenty of animals to track and hunt. It's a refreshing departure from the mindless shooting galleries found in most other hunting games.

The game features a leveling system that rewards both player progression and weapon skill. As you level up, you unlock new weapons and gear, providing a satisfying sense of achievement. The journey culminates at Level 60, but fear not, for you can always start anew if you crave another round.

For those who enjoy missions, the base game (and DLCs) offers a variety of engaging quests. These provide in-game cash and experience for leveling up, making them a great way to acquire new equipment. However, missions are entirely optional, so you can chart your own course if you prefer.

When it comes to the numerous DLCs, fear not! In multiplayer, all hunting reserve DLCs are absolutely free to everyone, but single-player and equipment access will require purchase. The weapon pack DLCs are enjoyable but not necessary, as the base game weapons provide a similar experience. Other DLCs like ATVs, dogs, blinds, and tree stands offer convenience but don't add much beyond time-saving. Personally, I prefer to enjoy exploring on foot rather than zooming by on an ATV, scaring off all the wildlife.

If you're uncertain about diving in, keep an eye out for one of the frequent sales, both for the base game and the DLCs. It may not be the most hardcore hunting simulator, but its powerful blend of simulation and gameplay elements creates a truly enjoyable and immersive hunting adventure. You’ll be addicted in no time.

While this game has it's issues, those being rather minor minor occasional glitches that are usually ironed out, it's easily the best and most enjoyable hunting game ever made.  With many reserves to choose from, ranging all across the world, there is no shortage of game to hunt.  From the standard White-tail Deer all the way to an African Lion, what you want to hunt is entirely up to you.  Weapon variety is solid, including rifles, pistols, bows, and handguns of all sizes.

The game is beautiful and fun to wander around in.  After 200 hours, I still get the shakes when I spot a diamond down in the valley, call it in, and attempt that fatal shot.

Update after almost 500 hours:  I've played a lot of multiplayer recently and it's definitely a positive in this game. If you have the DLC maps, you can invite your friends to play, whom may not have one of the reserves, and they can play on your version of the reserve without having to pay. It makes getting into the game and also deciding which maps you like/don't like a little less costly.

Many potential players will ask, "Will I like this game or not".
To which my response is always with these questions:
[list]
[*]Do you hunt in real life?
[*]Do you like a more slow paced/relaxed game?
[*]Do you enjoy the thrill of the hunt, even if that hunt may take 3 hours
just for that one good shot at a single trophy animal?
[*]Do you enjoy games where you can team up with friends and/or strangers
and have a good laugh?
[*]Do you enjoy open world games with multiple maps, and awesome graphics?
[/list]

If you answered yes to some of those questions then maybe this game is
for you, however if you think that you can run around everywhere getting
headshots on every animal you see then I'm sorry, but you're going to
be disappointed and maybe this game isn't for you. If you are still not
sure then there is always youtube for those that may want to do some
more research.

Ok then to start off with, playing the Hunter: Call of the Wild requires
planning, skill, and alot of patience, you will need to use the terrain
to your advantage, while keeping a close eye on the wind direction, your
noise level, and the visibility meter as well. Sure (like most games
these days) it has it's bugs, but the Hunter: Call Of The Wild is still
reasonably early on in development compared to Expansive Worlds other
hunting game, so it can hopefully only get better with time.
I've had the game for awhile now, and I still make a backup save manually
from time to time just to be on the safe side, and for any new players you
should also do the same.  Manually backing up your save file and putting it
somewhere else on your machine can save ALOT of frustration. It can be
really annoying to have mission resets, loss of in-game currency,
loss of XP, and levels. It is perhaps, the biggest issue the game has
right now unfortunately.

Don't be put off though, I haven't had any of these major bugs happen to
me, and apart from the occasional crash every now and then, I've had an
awesome experience playing this. It's one of those games that is easy to
pick up, but hard to master, so to help get you started there are plenty
of singleplayer missions for you to complete, from photo missions to
hunting specific animals, there is plenty to do and will take sometime
to finish them all. The multiplayer side of things is very good too, and
while I consider this to be the most bug filled part in the Hunter: Call
Of The Wild, it is still awesome to play, especially with friends.

So then with all of that being said, I absolutely recommend this game to
any and all, you don't necessarily need to be a real life hunter to enjoy
this game, and with a vast array of DLC to choose from, (I recommend the
other hunting reserves, the Weapon Packs, and the High Tech Hunting Pack
to start off with) grab this game and get the lead out.

Thanks for reading, and if you get this game, happy hunting.

I picked this up during the Summer Sale on a whim and a few months later it is somehow my 4th most played game of all time, and that is during a year when I have had precious little playtime due to work and other responsibilities. What I thought might be an interesting diversion for a few plays unexpectedly became an obsession that I wish I'd taken a chance on much earlier. There is quite simply nothing else out there even remotely like this game. It's Fallout: NV meets Dear Esther meets.. old school Everquest rare spawn camping? Oh, and there's hunting as well.

The world is amazingly well realized, with the many different reserves each offering a gorgeous and serene environment in which to complete quests (missions) ranging from killing a certain animal with a certain weapon to the more straight forward "Go to this campsite and see if the yoga instructor there was eaten by a bear." (Spoiler alert, she was eaten by the fucking bear). The AI of the animals you hunt is incredible. The living world moves on whether you interact with it or not as the other inhabitants go about their daily routines of travelling, resting, eating, and drinking. They act realistically to sound, sight, and smell, and you must behave accordingly or you'll scare them off before you even see them. Note: Much like real life hunting, the game requires patience and if you lack that, this may not be for you. But even  in sessions where I saw precious few animals, the zen quality of just existing in the various reserves was never a waste of time. 

After a hard day, coming home and escaping into this world has been the best gaming experience I have had in a long time. If you think this may even remotely be up your alley, take a chance! I recommend getting all of the DLC in a bundle during the sale, as it is all worthwhile. My only caveat is that the devs quit adding new Achievements and Side Missions to the last few DLC packs, which lowers the replayability. Some have also bemoaned the addition of cosmetics, but they can largely be ignored and they have even given several packs away for free.

Disclaimer: I've payed for all the DLCs, because I don't like the butchered versions of my games. I've only played on Layton Lakes so far. I know about the shooting range in Hirschfelden, but it does not negate my second point.

This game is fun for me and I'll keep playing it. However, it suffers from the following:

1. Too many bugs (e.g. AI pathfinding is atrocious — animals, including your paid DLC dog, constantly bump into and/or get blocked by boulders; sometimes my gadget breaks and I can't see any marked tracks on its display, not even my dog indicator, so I lose sight of my dog, I have to restart the game in a middle of a pursuit of a wounded animal — it's so frustrating). This breaks the immersion significantly. Also, did I mention the crashes?
2. It is extremely grindy. It's almost impossible to enjoy this game in a casual manner. You can't jump in and simply test your gear (some of which is paywalled, but more on that later) right away, as you can in Arma 3, for example.
3. When you begin to play, you're given extremely limited information about the behaviours and the states of the animals. You're bound to read external guides and maps, if you hate wasting your time.
4. At the beginning, you don't have access to decent ammunition (higher penetration is what you should be aiming for, don't waste your in-game money for hollow-points, as I did). This results in an extreme disadvantage in long range shots (which are almost the only shots you'll have the opportunity to take at the beginning, because you haven't learned to be patient/silent and don't know about the fact that you need to crouch-walk/crawl all the føkken time yet and you spook animals 200 metres away before you're even able to see them).
5. Software-as-a-service "business model" scam + paywalls everywhere = a game that most people expect to enjoy in a singleplayer. Føkk this 5#1+, I am so sick of it.
6. If you decide that you want a less arcadey and more of a simulator experience, you can turn off the highlighting of the animal tracks. However, it's very hard to notice them that way if you're just starting to play, unless they are very well illuminated (most of the time they are not). Then, you have the option of buyng a DLC - the bloodhound. It can do the following of bloodtrails/droppings for you somewhat reliably. Doesn't make it a piece of cake, though, it's still kinda tough to pursue an animal which you couldn't shoot in the organs for some reason (cf. point 4).
7. If you decide that you wanna cosplay as Robin Hood, I mean, you decide to go with a bow/crossbow, then get ready for lots of frustration and even more grind. Before you get the hang of distance estimation and arrow drop which naturally comes after many hours of experience (you need your animals to be around 30 metres away from you — good luck not spooking them with the tiniest noise you make while crouched/prone), you will give up and pay more money for the tripod/treestand (yes, they are paywalled).
8. Get ready to re-download the whole game (30GB download, 60 GB installation) after every single update. Good luck with the reduced lifespan of your SSD. I'm sorry, but this is føkken ridiculous.
9. The zeroing is arcadey and has fixed values (25/50/75 metres or 75/150/300 metres). You will not actually learn how much of a struggle (especially for an unsupervised beginner, such as I am) it is to zero a weapon IRL.
10. You must pay in-game money for sleeping in a cabin (e.g. you want to fast forward to daylight, because you føkken hate not being able to see 5#1+ during the night, because the night-vision scope & night-vision binoculars are paywalled).
11. Oh, yeah, in-game money is hard to come by. The prices for some weapons (some of which are required for quests, e.g. the .45-70 lever action rifle costs 48000 money) are insanely high (cf. point 2). Also, don't waste your in-game money for the hunting structures (as I did) — they are overpriced and are next to useless (offering limited angles and distances).
12. Some of the quests require luck, not skill.

That's all I can think of right now, I'm sure there's more.

A few good things:
a) The game looks and sounds beautiful. Unfortunately, this wears off quickly, after you get acquainted with the flaws I mentioned above (especially point 1).
b) You will learn a thing or two about shot placement. As Paul Harrell said (while discussing the legal consequences of participating in a citizen-involved shooting): "there is no replacement for shot placement".
c) It's fun only if you can accept the grindiness.
d) To appreciate the autoloaders (before you ask — yes, the ARs are paywalled), you will need to make the game a little bit "harder" for you. Go to Settings -> Game -> turn off "Auto chambering". Now, every bolt action rifle/pump action shotgun/single-action revolver will have to be c0ck3d manually (default button R) after each shot. You will appreciate the autoloaders' IRL added value (yes, the semi-automatics are also referred to as "autoloaders").
e) (EDIT from 23-NOV-2022) I'm giving a "Labour of love" nomination, since I'm willing to bet that almost all the problems are due to poor management & lead game designer decisions, not because the people who actually create the game are incompetent/lazy/scammers.

EDIT from November 21st, 2023:
It gets a second "labour of love" nomination from me for the same reasons mentioned above.

The Hunter Call of the Wild has to be one of the best hunting games out there! I've spent many hours playing this game alone and with friends; it is incredible! I need to play it more! The animals behave well and are realistic as far as a game can make them! So many funny things happen in this game, especially with friends! Sometimes glitches happen, but they often are comical, rarely game-breaking. There are a wide variety of weapons, too! It's not overly challenging, yet not too easy. It's just an excellent game for pros and beginners alike!
This is the best hunting game I have ever played. Enjoyable and very relaxing.

10 hours in, game is eye candy, huge and varied in environment. Animals are easily spooked and it needs one to arm himself with a patience, because hunting is slow-paced. Travelling without ATV DLC is slow (DLC recommendedú but there's many "wow" moments over the theater play of environment and weather. UI needs a rework, I was confused in inventory for a minute or two when I wanted to swap callers equipment). There's two maps now but if you want to play the second one, you lose all progress of first one (needs to change, make it more convenient for player). Still has some quirks here and there but overall best singleplayer hunting game I played.

EDIT 11/2023: Still the best hunting experience out there.

I remember when the Devs announced this game they promised it wouldn't turn out like their previous game 'theHunter' with micro-transactions or micro-DLC or keep vital game features behind a paywall. They said they would only release normal Map DLC, and surely 
the first DLC was Medved-Taiga, it looked like they were keeping true to their promise. Shortly after that they released the Quad DLC, while arguably not vital, gamers already predicted they were straying away from the promise.

Recently they've announced paid customization like skins for weapons and probably more to come. We've come full circle and it shows greed never changes. Instead of repairing bugs, sticking with map DLCs or moving on to another project they are making this choice. The've lost my support, period.

When it first released it was a quality hunting simulator, in an age where those were doomed to retarded levels of realism and graphics worse than ugly. Nowadays simulators are popular and there is decent competition in every niche. Instead of innovating and positioning them firmly within one segment they chose the easy money way out.

It's not possible to really hunt in my country so I can't argue about realism, however it's still a game and a balance needs to be struck. Still, I am a veteran gamer and I can recognize quality game-play and performance and I also recognize a cash-grab, this is one! So sad for a game that once was a much more.

Changing my review on 11/21/2023. This game unfortunately suffers from some greedy devs who feel the need to charge for every single idea they come up with. As far as I am aware the new Labrador will be a separate $5 DLC, when it should be included with the bloodhound pack. If I am incorrect about that then I will change this part of my review to be correct, though I am still keeping my stance on a negative review. They also charge for every new map that comes out and every new weapons pack that comes out. So, they charge for separate pets, separate weapons packs, and each individual map that comes out. that is a lot of ways they are bringing in money and some of which fair enough but it's still a lot, especially when some should be included with others. The devs also seem to not know very much about firearms, because I shouldn't be looking at the sky after shooting a .300 or a .308. The recoil is very over dramatized and should be adjusted for many of the firearms, as well as the ammo capacities. It is insane that you have firearms like the 4570 which only holds 3 but a real life counter part can hold 8. I understand that there should be challenges within the game but there should be a middle ground somewhere. With all this being said I think I have been enjoying way of the hunter a bit more. I haven't had the chance to play it multiplayer yet so I wont give that one a review yet but I do think it is worth considering over this title.

I like this game alot, it's just a nice relaxing game to kill some time on.

There's alot of different animals you can hunt and the game rewards patient and smart play pretty well, while also giving you a pretty decent starting rifle that even has free ammo you can get from the shop infinitely. The starting rifle is also capable of comfortably taking almost all of the most common animals in the game, so it's not a cheap cop-out like alot of other game's starting guns. Most of the DLC maps also come with a pretty decent free weapon you can unlock by just running around and doing missions for the wardens, so you even get rewarded for actually engaging with the story, if you choose to call it that.

unfortunately... I have a few gripes I have to bring up.

There's a persistent bug that I've had in this game since I bought it where on basically all of the DLC maps besides the taiga, no animal track markers appear no matter what settings I tamper with, even though in the non-DLC maps, they appear just fine. This basically means finding anything in the DLC maps for me comes down to pure luck. This also applies to blood trails. They can be found and interacted with, but again there's no trail or directional cone, so I kinda get bullied by the game into having to bring the dog along to find any animals I shoot, which kinda cucks you since the dog can spook animals if you're tracking an animal you didn't kill in one shot, starting your whole chase all over again.

It's a little shameful that such a fundamental necessity of the game has this issue and nothing I do seems to actually fix it, from pressing C to toggle tracks, to using the binoculars, to resetting all the settings in the menu, to even a full uninstall and reinstall... 

Alot of the best weapons and hunting is locked into the DLC content and this could probably be a sore point for alot of people. I don't see it as a big issue since the game DOES need to make money to keep getting support, but it does mean some of the base guns can feel a bit bland at times. Alot of the more fun guns in the base game are also pretty brutally priced, or locked behind level requirements that can make the game feel pretty grindy to get the fun guns you want. It almost feels like paying for success, even though the base guns are all perfectly good.

As much as I personally love this game, and do wholeheartedly recommend it if you like hunting games, the issues I keep having with it cripple the game for me and until the game either cooperates with me or I can figure it out, It gets bumped from an 8/10 from me down to a 6/10 since there's literally an entirely necessary aspect of the game that is non-functional for me for no discernible reason.

There isnt quite anything like this game that I have played (due bear in my mind this is my only real exposure to a hunting game). I have spent a lot of time in the game in the included maps and a few dlcs i picked up, and there is no game that sucks me in quite like this one. It is just so peaceful and full of life that on occasion I am content with just walking around!
The gun play and the hit registry is pretty good from what I can tell with the occasional mishap (like any other game). Sometimes the AI animals are very not intelligent and can be found getting caught on the terrain semi regularly, but in general they are faithful to behavior in real life.
I highly recommend you get a dlc map or two (my personal favorites are the emerald coast and yukon valley as my all time favorite, and in my opinion, are a must have if you want to get this game and experience the best it can offer)
This game is worth every cent I put into it, including the dlc. Everything is wonderful and feels unique in its own way. There are so many stories you can make in your mind because of how the game is structured.

if you feel like running around and going on a rampage against the wildlife being an eco-terrorist, you can do that!
If you want to try and be stealthy in your approach for a particularly rare set of antlers on a deer, you can do that!
If you want to drive your atv (dlc required) around and decide you want to go exploring for fun and look at the VERY expansive terrain, you can do that!
The system requirements are not strenuous, so this will run on even integrated graphics a lot of the time on modern CPUs. 

Would recommend, 9.5/10
not a ten because of the breaks of immersion that happen at times.

I really liked this game. The graphics are amazing, the map are overall cool, the gameplay is slow but very rewarding.
I have however, several problems with the game :

- The dlcs sometimes ruin the experience by giving op weapons, and sometimes just buggy and uninteresting maps. You can really tell when they don't put any effort in a dlc, like the cammo ones. They even lock some basic features like the quad or the tripods behind paywall, a bit greedy in my opinion.
- The quests are bad most of the time, and if in some maps (like the free ones) they're decent and at least have some objective, in others they just want you to walk to see if a random lake isn't poluted or if Joe is back from his trip in the old mine. I wish the quests would interact with the world a bit more and maybe add to the progression system which is mid imo. Some quests are also sometimes not not doable, like it asks to hunt blacktail deer in a zone where there are none to be found.
- The multiplayer doesn't add anything to the base game (except your friends), it even removes the possibility to do quests, and except from the challenges (wich give nothing, not even XP), there's no real goal. You're gonna have to set some for yourself.
- My biggest complain about this game is how the animals are so predictible. At least when you've played alot, you can see what they're gonna do, where they're gonna go, and where you're gonna be able to absolutely massacre them. If you haven't played this game yet, I recommend not checking any video on farming money or XP, or diamond animals, just enjoy the game. What has made me sad, is when after playing (kindof) roleplay (running from the bears, ambushing, using scents), I realised that I could just play like a brute and kill whatever I wanted.

So that's it, I still really like this game, I've played a lot with friends and solo, and it was great, until I discovered how easy it was to farm animals. Don't do like me and enjoy the game longer by not watching videos about it.

If you enjoyed theHunter Classic, you will be pleased to know that Cotw is a vast improvement. Granted, given that classic was a paywall ridden insanely slow paced camping shooter that doesn't take much.

Cotw as a base game offers a decent amount of animals, equipment, and varying play styles. Gone are the limitations of being yelled at for not having the gun/license needed for the animal. You can shoot down Bison with a pistol and use a shotgun on a rabbit. 

The base game also offers "aggressive" animals which pose a nice challenge of having to defend yourself after the initial shot. Or...you could full tilt run at the animal and like anyone with common sense, it will run screaming from the maniac with a gun repeatedly shooting at it until it dies. 

The graphics are gorgeous, even on low quality. There's several screenshots I have saved of just...photogenic areas. The controls aren't bad either. I only had to change 2 keybinds to suit my style.

That being said, there's some aspects of the game I thoroughly hate. 

The sound design being the biggest problem for me. I will say, I'm HoH and so usually my issue with games is being unable to hear the sounds. Not with Cotw. Instead, I'm wishing I could play completely silently. Cotw sounds are horror film style whisper until you turn the volume up and then blast you with the loudest thing ever. Whitetail deer scream louder than fnaf animatronics.

In a hunting game, sound is crucial for a lot of aspects. Trying to find that animal through calls or the crunch of foliage under its feet. Everything in Cotw makes a sound however. Everything. Even you when you're standing still. And sounds are seemingly random and lag behind actions. If I had a dime for every time I made a footstep crunch while crouched down on an outpost unmoving, I'd have enough to buy the full dlc.

And you know those scenes in movies where people fire guns into the air to quiet down a panicking crowd or get attention? Yeah, I do that now. For ducks/geese. The sounds for those infernal birds overtakes all other sounds. It's unbearable. So if I wind up near those beasts, I wind up sacrificing any hunt by madly firing my gun to get them to go away. 

Other than that, cotw is ultimately a walking sim and that can be pretty draining on your want to play for long. Pretty graphics but you can't sit and wait for animals to show up anymore because they seemed to overcompensate for previous camping by giving every single animal superman style super hearing. All animals can hear you for over 200 meters away. Even if you're doing nothing. So waiting in an outpost is just signing yourself up to hours of nothing.

Instead, you find yourself roaming around, waiting for an animal to spot you from far away, crouch and shuffle unbelievably slowly towards it. I don't hate it but I don't love it either. There are times I want to boot up this game and sit in a good hiding spot and wait. I haven't been able to do that at all.

Tracking your animal after you shoot it needs serious improvements. I'm low level so I don't know if the skills/perks help but I do know I could find a dead animal in classic far easier than I can in cotw. I spent 5 in game hours looking for the corpse of a bison. A BISON. It's not like it was hidden under a bush! And not to mention some corpses just vanish into thin air. You manage to hit that lucky shot and immediately kill the animal and poof there it goes. Raptured into heaven.

Overall, I'm enjoying cotw and there's some dlc I'm interested in. It's not a high energy game but I still feel accomplished when I nail a hunt. I'm curious to see what high leveling will give me and what other equipment I can unlock and mess with.

Dangerous hunting maps and games are the best kind. I love being attacked and have to defend myself. That Dino game was exactly that. Searching for them wasn't the case there, they searched for me. My friends loved this game as well. Such a let down and So sad it ended the way it did. Rip Primal.

From my point of view as a former soldier (6 yrs), national park ranger (10+ yrs), lifelong sporting shooter,  firearm enthusiast & long time video 'gamer',

The mechanics of the game are  reasonably well implemented  and polished and it appears the designers/ devs did their homework as far as  animal behaviour and hunting methods are concerned.

After playing this game a reasonable amount and taking some time away to reflect on the experience I cannot recommend it to anyone for the following simple reason:

Language and it's usage are important and from the very earliest days of firearms use and development there has been a very simple way to differentiate between firearms used as tools for hunting of animals for food/ sport - and their use as 'weapons' used to injure or kill human beings.

Firearms designed as tools for hunting/ food procurement are referred to as 'firearms' or guns.

Only firearms designed for use against humans are referred to as 'weapons'. 

History has shown this distinction to be critically important time and again in more ways than it would be possible to recount here.

Obviously and unfortunately there are instances where hunting firearms are/ have been used against people as 'weapons'. This neither dilutes nor diminishes the importance of referring to them as what they were designed for - "this hunting rifle was used as a 'weapon' against a person during a self defence emergency".

This hunting games' insistence on using the term 'weapon' to describe hunting firearms smacks of the same rhetoric and intentional twisting/ misuse of language currently being used to push legislative changes that would disarm the populations of every western country you care to name. A similar decades long campaign by anti gun zealots has seen widespread uptake of the nonsensical term 'assault' rifle to describe carbines of all make and manner (even airsoft guns in some places??).

Sad really, and whether this developer choice was made out of sheer ignorance (unlikely given they obviously had experienced hunters advising them) or with the intent to subtly reinforce anti gun messaging is largely immaterial - the damage is done.

Avoid this game and be sure your kids know how to spot anti gun/ anti human rights indoctrination in all media.

Best wishes

This game is incredibly hard to recommend, this game has been out for so long, and there are still such horrendous absolutely game breaking bugs and problems that it's just sad.
I love this game, i sunk a lot of time and money into it, but every day i play i just get slapped in the face. In ways i feel like Cabela's hunting games are more fun.

The current most biggest bug i've been experiencing lately are "ghost bullets", I can have the perfect animal right in front of me, clear open field with nothing to accidentally hit, rifle is zeroed correctly, aim perfectly at the lungs, and yet when i fire magically there is no bullet; what would have been a kill shot turned into firing a blank and scaring off the animal.
This occurs so frequently i'm right about to just quit playing entirely and move over to another game.

Another issue with the game is DLC's, so many of these things should have been free to begin with, the whole team behind this game are so money hungry- and even with all that money they cant even produce a decent game, its genuinely laughable how sad the creators are of this mess.

I would only tell people to get this game if you've already tried all the other hunting games, this game used to be one of the best hunting games out there, even years ago with all the other bugs, but it only seems to be getting worse- in terms of bugs and overall effort, the more maps and dlc's they push out for money the sadder and more of the same they all start to become.
These Swedes are a joke.
Even their newest game- theAngler was an absolute flop, like legit terrible.


Oh, and this game is just cringe as well, it's a game all about hunting, right? Well every single main story mission on each map is a f%cking Scooby-Doo mystery and all you do is run around the map pushing E on whatever they want you to, it's so boring and stupid. I'm here to brain little animals not be the detective in a children's book.

EDIT: New bug to me, animals straight up vanishing in thin air right in front of me. Legit quitting this game for a solid year, if they dont fix their sh#t i am never returning.


[HEY DEVS] Make clothing do something like it did in Classic. (i.e. certain clothes reduce your scent, noise, and vision).
 If you aren't going to make guns 100% steady when holding breath AND having all the points for steady breath- just add a bipod we can silently deploy before shots.
Make animals behave like actual animals, stop making them just walk constantly until they eventually get to their need zone- if i startle call they should sit there and watch closely for a while, not either ignore it completely or immediately run off.
Make the scope/binocular sensitivity consistent- for ex. its stupid to have 4x zoom be 0.25 sens and 8 zoom be 1.0
Make sitting in blinds and calling actually worth it, need zones are meta and boring. 99.9% of the time its better to just run around and shoot everything that moves.
Get rid of hunting pressure, just make animals actually dynamic.
Add a way to sit down- so you can get the same height as crouching, but with the same visibility as crawling, and you cant move.

A game with a great atmosphere, good audio design, decent gun play, cool shot tracking and animal skins rarity system.

Like C'mon I live in australia but you could give us some aboriginal art weapon skins to unlock or something, the maps just end up feeling so cookie cutter despite the environmental and animal differences.

Feels like people who love hunting and have no knowledge of game or mechanic design lucked out and made a serviceable game. but I have 0 faith they'll fix anything or provide any user friendly features in the future which is an utter disapointment.

I have to resort to the Couso Model 1897 mounted next to my gold rated moose loaded with 16 GA Buckshot, the pellets shred two bears in the blast, the sound and extra shrapnel setting off warning thumps from 327-456m away. Im not a hunter myself, but I love the way this game strives to emulate the real hunting experience in a video game. It adds a lot of depth to what would otherwise be a Point n Click kill game and makes it feel more satisfying to play! 

I also love this game as a Walking In The Forest Simulator, to be honest. I do play to hunt, but I cannot understate how much peace I feel in exploring regions of the world I'll never go to. Or, in the case of New England Mountains, it lets me go back to a place I havent had the chance to return to (born and raised Mainer here).

 Its a beautiful game, from the scenery to the animals to the attention to detail on the guns, and the fact it goes on sale so often and keeps adding new maps and animals to hunt keeps it from feeling stale! Absolutely love it

Your lust for blood has driven you in endless circles, chasing the cries of children in some unseen chamber, always seeming so near, yet somehow out of reach, but you will never find them. There's a lot to complain about and I'll get into that below, but despite all that it is still a unique immersive experience that I do quite enjoy. It's fun to choose your weapon loadout to hunt with, it's relaxing to roam around nature reserves and they look stunning. Depth to the sneaking and shooting mechanics keeps you engaged. You never know what's going to happen. It varies between slow and (very) exciting. For example, you may suddenly be charged by a bear while you have your pea shooter out lining up a shot on a small animal. No two sessions are the same.

[h1]Bugs[/h1]
There are far too many. Here's some examples. There's an age old bug causing region names to no longer appear on the map so you don't know where a mission is trying to tell you to go. I found a dirt road texture hovering above the ground where it was supposed to be. Grass (which is everywhere) will flicker on a map released 5 years ago, but not consistently. One playsession it will be fine, the next it'll happen constantly. I keep running into glitched spots where one block of terrain meets another with an invisible collision box that makes you walk straight up into the air instead the direction you're trying to go. Iron sights are often misaligned. You sometimes crawl through rocks instead of over them when prone. There are white lines connecting parts of mountains and hills together like glued back together ceramic vases.

The devs' parent company recently opened a new office in Manhattan, one of the most expensive locations on the planet. Now you know where all that DLC money is going instead of being used to hire QA testers and programmers focused on bug fixing.

The reason this developer still exists is a lack of serious competition in a niche genre.

[h1]Lazy game design decisions[/h1]
There are so many examples of this I could spend hours listing them all. I'll mention a few so you kinda get the idea. No reward for exploration despite awful movement over rough terrain, can't interact with objects (there aren't any character animations for that) or even knock over a trash bin. Lookout towers, important locations, are copy/pasted clones with no interaction with any of the furniture inside - you can only open/close doors. Opening / closing a glass sliding door out to the porch, the same audio sample is played as for a normal wooden door inside. Trampolines outside cannot be used and if you jump on one from a higher position you'll land on the air above it, unable to reach its surface. Shooting a soccer ball instead of an animal will make the ball bleed because a bloody decal is placed on it.

The maps have nature and animals, that's it. Nothing else. You can either shoot the animals or be bored out of your skull. What if I get bored of shooting animals, you ask? My point exactly, even though that will keep you busy for longer than you think there's obviously an expiration date.

Collisions between animals and the quad bike (ATV DLC) are all wrong and result in the player taking HP damage, seeing a red flash and just bouncing off of the animal which doesn't even get pushed off its course it was running on.

There's points of interest with flavor text and a handful of "artifacts" to be found through exploration of each map/reserve. They're so lame it's laughable that the developer thinks these are truly interesting to the player. Makes you feel like the game designer has never played a game before. It's just filler.

No gamma/brightness settings, no fps limiter. The only anti-aliasing modes available are "FXAA" and "FXAA + TAA". You can't enable contact shadows (which add a lot of nice contrast to grass / foliage) without enabling "FXAA + TAA". Without AA, tree canopies are unrealisticially pixel-y / grainy and both AA modes on offer degrade the raw image quality by softening things too much. Only when "FXAA + TAA" is enabled does the game let you enable sharpening (a custom amount) and it's not able to undo all of the damage. As another side effect of TAA, canopies (and grass) in motion are smeared out blobs until they stop moving.

[h1]Missions[/h1]
The game is very, very light on story. You don't meet NPC's in the actual game world. Missions are presented by voice over + on screen static avatar in the UI. They're tasks with some made up reason / background info for them handed to you in what is mainly a sandbox experience of hunting animals on a vast map. By tasks I mean, e.g. kill animal type X from a hunting stand in location Y. There may not even be any of those animals in that area which is another problem with the game. After waiting several in-game days I ended up using the ATV DLC to scare animals into the area from elsewhere. (Essential DLC if you don't want to spend hours walking to get from A to B.)

[h1]Closing thoughts[/h1]
It takes a huge amount of patience to play theHunter. I still enjoy the game but it's definitely not for everyone. If you run or even just walk upright through vegetation, you'll spook every animal and never even see any. You have to slow yourself to a crawl, often literally. It's fun to mess around with different weapon loadouts. This game is to hunting almost what Sniper Elite 4 is to sniping: somewhat game-ified. E.g. ammo calibres aren't realistic.

It won't make most people's all-time top 10 but it has enough going for it to be some people's absolute favorite game. It offers a unique, slower paced, immersive experience with plenty of exciting moments too. After hundreds of hours I personally still enjoy it a lot. Objectively it's about a 7.5 out of 10 as the lack of production quality and devs' carelessness detract from the experience. If the devs weren't so lazy it could've easily been a 9 out of 10.

One of the best coop experiences I have had, surprisingly enough. I would have thought it to be utterly boring and uncooperative with a friend, but it's really cool. While you're just walking you can have a nice chat, enjoying the surroundings. And when there's game in sight, you can help each other (one with binoculars for instance, the other creeping closer and guiding them, or both taking a simultaneous hit on bigger game, or both getting closer from different angles, etc. etc.). And there's the occasional wild episode where a bunch of bizons attack you and you can WIld West your way out of there together. All in all very immersive and a great mix of relaxation and suspense. Really very, very enjoyable. 
Give it time to get acquainted with the game however, it took me some 15-20 hours to just get a grasp of what it could be about... Very much recommended!

Updating this now that I've played this game 10x more since my original review. One of the most scenic games I have ever came across, and I truly am happy I did. Each reserve is created with detail, and each has its own astonishing, and unique features that frankly never makes this game dry in my opinion. The large database of animals you can hunt from small game like waterfowl, to big game like Bison, make this game a unique choice out of all the hunting games available on the market. 

As the well, the ease to access any reserve using multiplayer is very helpful. Before getting invested in this game, using multiplayer reserves to test out which DLC I wanted was a great way to slowly expand, but still get the experience I wanted. As well, the multiplayer itself, even though it has its fair share of bugs, is a great way to enjoy the game with friends.

To be honest, the majority of negative reviews for COTW are because of the content that is locked behind the DLC paywall. My opinion? Well yes, it's annoying initially, I think the first two base layer maps and weapons give you an idea on the game and allow you to decide if you want to further invest into it. Do I think that some DLCs should be free content with the base layer, sure. It would scare off less new players who are looking for an enjoyable time. But at the same time, the DLCs are relatively cheap, especially during sales, which I heavily suggest you take the opportunity up as DLCs become almost half the price.

Graphics wise, it's an absolutely stunning game. The environment, the animal models, I believe everything is just about perfection in this game for me. It truly makes me feel like I've been teleported to the Yukon, or that I feel and see the heat of the Vurhonga Savanna. It isn't super tolling on my PC as well, and I actually played this game comfortably on a laptop for my first year or so.

Overall, with the constant updates in content, I can confidently say this outweighs any other hunting game on the market, by a longshot. If you properly invest your time into this game, maybe invest in some DLCs, you'll experience the true beauty of the game that cannot be described by me, but rather must be experienced by yourself.

Finally updating my review from a negative one to a positive one. I'll leave my old review below this one, just so you can see my previous opinion of the game. Not every issue I talked about is resolved yet, and the developers are still extremely slow pushing out bug fixes (the stuttering scope bug when holding your breath is still not fixed after about 2-3 years, and I even reported it and talked to a developer about the issue), but it's better than before. The game is playable now. The recent changes to the game have been mostly positive and so were the content patches. I'm having fun playing this again, so I guess that speaks for itself. I used to simply be frustrated all the time. The game is good now. Let's hope it stays that way.

Here's my old review in case you want to read it. It was a negative one:

---

I love this game, I really do. When everything works, it's the most amazing and most immersive experience I've ever had in a video game. It's both relaxing and exciting at the same time, and there's infinite replay value. The atmosphere is amazing, the graphics are great, the animal AI is great, the weapons are great, it's all great.

So why do I not recommend this game then? Because nothing actually works. It's a giant buggy mess with incompetent developers that are either too lazy or don't care to fix their game. The game is not complex at all (it's not like it's an MMO or something). You walk around some terrain, you shoot animals and you collect the rewards. That's about it. Yet every aspect of this contains at least one or more bugs. You want to change scopes? Bugged. You want to zoom in? Camera stutter. You want to walk through bushes? The sound persists after you leave the bush. You want to look through the binoculars? Have fun with 0,00001 mouse sensitivity, because the devs don't know how to implement zoom scaling. You want to ride on the ATV in the dark? Lights don't work.

Some bugs have been in the game for months or even years. Every new patch they release, introduces more bugs that are never resolved, unless we're extremely lucky. Reports do nothing, the devs acknowledge nothing.

And it's not just the bugs, the game just isn't polished. From the lack of zoom scaling, to the messy interface and interactions with the world map, it just feels so rushed and poorly developed. It's just bad, sooo bad. And I really want to love this game, but nowadays I'm just more frustrated than anything. And that is really, really unfortunate.

Mechanically, this is a great game with nice graphics, nice soundtrack, nice gunplay if you aren't super stingy about ballistics. HOWEVER, 95% of the game is DLC behind paywalls. I will continue to play with the DLC that I bought so that I get my money's worth but I don't recommend buying this game if you do not support greedy companies OR if you think you will get bored of the base game maps and the base game guns.

Probably the best hunting game out there right now, and it's genuinely good. But it's REALLY hard to recommend it currently, since nearly every update is a paid DLC, like a reserve/map, a weapon pack, cosmetic pack, etc. Which all costs real money and adds up quickly. There's no way to unlock any of it for free either, which their old game theHunter Classic actually allowed you to do (once they started making this game and abandoned Classic lol)

They also make you pay to use ATV's (or quads), which are the only way you can traverse the huge maps quickly without walking. I will mention that you CAN play on the new maps for free whenever they release, but you can't do missions, buy weapons that come with the reserve, or host servers on those maps.

So basically if you don't pay any money for DLC's, you just have the base game content to do and that's pretty much it, unless you want to hunt animals on the DLC reserves which can be sorta fun but there's no actual progression or stuff to unlock at that point. Currently I would recommend picking this up on sale, but just keep in mind that most of the content is locked behind paid DLC.

theHunter: Call of the Rambo. Is this a good hunting game? Well, it depends on what you want from it. If you've ever been hunting or actually know a thing a two about guns you'll figure out pretty quickly that there are some serious flaws, as I go hunting every year. I'll get the "bad" stuff outta the way first then dive into the good stuff, because it is still an immensely enjoyable game despite those flaws. The game for me has went from a hunting simulator to, depending on my mood, a Rambo simulator or a game to relax to.

Cons: 
I've returned to edit the review as I've now got more time under the ol' belt.

-The ballistics aren't as awful as I initially thought they were. Are they perfect? No, they're not too bad but can be annoying at times so it's a small con. Unless you get charged by anything threatening and you clap the gal in the forehead with a .338 rifle and it shrugs it off. Then it's a big problem, but that's not even remotely a deal breaker.

- Animations get weird at times, there are bugs from time to time that get annoying but, on the other hand, can be hilarious. Put an ATV at the bottom of the tall bridge in Yukon Valley and jump down on top of it from that height, you'll see what I mean as you enter orbit.

Pros:

- It's gorgeous, all of the effects and environments look spectacular at times and really make the game a treat to look at.

- It sounds wonderful, the music, the gunshots, the animals, environmental sounds, all are great and make it very easy to get lost in and explore for hours.

- It's funny, there's nothing quite like sneaking up on a fox with an enormous rifle and blasting it from 20 yards out just to watch it roll along the ground from the force of the impact.

- It's satisfying, due to the relatively bad ballistics mentioned earlier, animals will typically run for quite some time if you shoot them from any sort of range past 175 yards, which can make tracking them extremely enjoyable as you look for the monster of a Buffalo you shot while crawling around in the underbrush. It's nice to finally roll up on the kill and be reminded that yes, you truly are the god of the forest in this game.

- Rambo, when feeling aggressive the world is your stomping ground. Buy 100 shells and shoot literally everything. I've found bodies that I didn't even know I'd shot as I stomp my way through the forest, laying waste to all who stand before me like Pol Pot on a cocaine binge. Definitely a good time.

TLDR; great game with minor annoyances. Would buy again at full price.

This is a great game, and an especially great value if you wait for a major sale to pick up all the DLC. I was able to get everything for less than $40 during the most recent Summer sale. 

Some people might not like the approach to monetization and consider it "nickel and dime," but I've personally seen much worse dollar-to-value ratios from almost any SaaS game I've played. (12.49 btw 🦀)

Unlocking the maps by visiting all the way points (ala Assassins Creed or Zelda BOTW/TOTK) creates a compelling narrative structure that gives you a reason to explore and hunt along the way. The environments are an absolute pleasure to experience as well. Great sound design, atmosphere, and attention to detail. You can tell this is a labor of love made by a small team, and I'm increasingly appreciating this kind of game over triple-A garbage rushed out by the cadavers of formerly-great game studios and their hedge fund puppeteers.

This is a good game if your opinion of a "good hunting game" is a game where the core gameplay loop is about essentially gambling your time and good hunting/shooting to potentially get bigger and better trophies. If you are looking for a realistic simulator then maybe this is not exactly the game you are hoping for.

A lot of the higher level gameplay revolves around grinding need zones as efficiently as possible, to where you will end up killing hundreds of animals in a session. The upsides to this are it makes the game depend a lot less on your patience, since you always know where and when to be to get your herds, and also it's pretty easy to do and casual players shouldn't have a hard time getting cool trophies. However if you don't play this way, it will probably take an eternity to find diamonds or rare furs in singleplayer, and you may as well give up on ever seeing a GO. 

So although theres other things to do like explore and do missions and stuff, you aren't going to get the full gameplay experience without at least a bit of grinding. So I think whether you enjoy this game depends on whether or not you are ok with that.

Where do I even start? This has to be one of the most boring games I've played in years. It'll take hours just to find a single animal, and even if you do find one it'll spot you and run away before you can even blink. And the skill tree in the game is completely useless. If you can hope to kill a few animals, then you'll get a single skill point, which you can redeem for basically nothing. And so the point of the skill tree is to make the game easier as it goes on, but shouldn't it start easy and get harder? And the tutorial taught me absolutely nothing, I'm not even sure if it was a tutorial, it just felt like something the developers threw together in 5 minutes.

Unless you're bored and looking to get even more bored, then I don't recommend this game.
