12 Ways Call of the Wild Got Nerfed

1. Male/Female Ratios: They used to be 50/50. Now males, the diamond producers for most species, are 25 percent or worse, especially among birds. In nature, that just doesn't happen. Result? Diamonds are harder to get.

2. Waterfowl used to be in the water. Now they hide behind trees, and lie in long grass. Yep, they eat worms, I guess. Result? Diamonds are harder to get.

3. Gunshot noise was increased. It used to be 200 meters. Now it's 270. So everything spooks in every direction. Result? Diamonds are harder to get.

4. Spook speed was increased. It used to be that antlered species would take a couple of seconds after hearing a shot to orient themselves and then run. Now they run instantly. No more multiple harvests from the same herd. Same with all the other species. And waterfowl spook like bullets. Result? Yep. Diamonds are harder to get.

5. Spook distance was increased. When animals ran from a shot, they used to return within a reasonable time. Now, they run, run, run. Faaaar away. Often, never to return. Result? Your guessed it. Diamonds are grindier than ever.

6. Wounded game take forever to go down. If you're an ethical hunter, you chase a wounded animal until you find it or it stops bleeding. Wounded animals now run more than twice the distance they used to. So while you're wasting time chasing 50 bloodspots, yep: Diamonds are harder to get.

7. The noise you make is now louder. Crawling on your belly used to make 25 meters of noise. Now it's 50. Every form of movement has had its noise distance increased by 25. Diamonds are already hard to get, but it's worse still...

8. Animals are more sensitive to your noise. Used to be you could crawl to within 10 meters of your game, in spite of the 25 meters of noise you were making. Now, a crouch walk, supposedly 75 meters of noise, will alert deer 100 meters away. Anyone wish they could get more diamonds?

9. Maximum level game now produces far more trolls. The level 3 deer, the level 5 moose and the level 9 water buffalo love to troll. It started with feral goats. One level 5 goat in 10 might produce a diamond when they were introduced on Te Awaroa. Now all the species have been tainted with higher troll percentages. Any guess how this affects your future diamond collection?

10. Herds have been reduced. One of the most exciting things about Vurhonga's wildebeests was that they used to thunder around the African prairie in herds of 30 or more. Whitetail used to have as many as 15 in a herd. Ducks used to pool in groups of 40. Divide all those numbers by four now. Smaller herds? Less diamonds.

11. Calls are less effective. Fox used to love a good rabbit squeal. Now they're meh. One of the toughest diamonds in the game -- just got tougher.

12. And here's the worst nerf of them all: Entire map populations have been decimated. Maps used to sport 1500+ animals at any given time. Best guess is that maps now only have 600 animals wandering in their lonely circles. All in an effort to make the game more playable for computers that are 15 years old. Guess what? As someone who has harvested 64000 animals on this game, including 16000 golds and 400 diamonds -- it's not about the diamonds anymore. It's about the Great Ones. Having harvested 2 before the changes listed above, I was loving this game. Now, it's just a miserable, boring, ripped off shadow of the great game it used to be.

I'm done here. Devs who don't understand the power of frequent rewards in a game, don't understand how games work. I'll no longer reward them with my time or money.







I have experienced many iterations of this game, and the changes always include some major bugs -- the latest update nixed the bloodhound DLC.

But those eventually get fixed. So you make the adjustment, and wait three months for the next update.

What kills this game for me are the changes for change sake that do not enhance the game. Those never get fixed.

At one point in the past, waterfowl re-spawned consistently, so you'd have fresh new targets all the time. Now the only way you can get fresh re-spawns? Kill the entire flock. Otherwise the same old leftovers constantly fly around your entire map, the exact same flock reappearing when you fast travel to other locations in hopes of finding fresh birds.

It used to be that waterfowl were 50/50 in their gender split. Males are the real prize. Now they've nerfed that split to 20/80. Shoot two males, and now you've got 8 females forever flying the skies, attracting nothing but scorn because they'll never score diamond. Considering that Canadian geese mate for life, I'm guessing the ratio is more like 50/50 in real life. And for the life of me I can't figure out: Why the nerf?

Whitetail used to pause and orient themselves after hearing a shot, giving you a chance to get a second shot in for another deer. Now they insta-spook. Every encounter is now a one shot experience, which means way more running around the map, picking up one harvest at a time. Gone is the thrill of a second quick accurate shot. That one for me is a game killer.

Gun noise distance used to be 200m. That's the range at which animals run away when you pull the trigger.  Now they've increased it to 270m. Why? To make the game harder? Or more realistic, in some developer's mind? As a hunter in real life, I find the change debatable. As a gamer, the game is just less fun now.

The game, for certain species, used to have a variety of fur types. Used to be fun collecting trophies in the all the colors they came in. Now? They've nerfed those colors down to just a handful. I'm guessing all those colors were plugging up processor bandwidth. Not sure how.

Ducks used to be fun to hunt with a shotgun. On a good encounter, you could bag 5 or 6 with a shotgun. Now those little mallard fly like bullets -- no where close to real life. You need to be real good just to get two. What used to be fun is just plain boring now. I've resorted to hunting them at 200 meters with a .22. I'm guessing I'll have to hunt at 250m now, with the augmented gun noise change.

I could go on, but instead...I'll just move on. I'll check into COTW every once in a while in the future. Maybe the developers will rediscover what really made this game great in the past.

But for now, after 62000 harvests and 388 diamonds,  I'll wave a sad goodbye.

I've been hunting many times, this game recreates all the worst parts of those experiences, and very few of the actual truths of hunting. You wanna get places faster in a vehicle? That'll be $7. Wanna have tree blinds, or tents? More money. A dog? may as well open up the ol wallet again... the amount of money you need to spend in order to feel like you can enjoy the game is a really high entry barrier that isn't worth broaching. Money aside, there are some factors that are even worse...

Never have I ever had a deer hear a twig snap 300 ft away and bolt away like it was an emergency. I have nearly hit sooooo many with a car IRL, walked up on dozens, my dog has pooped with one 20 feet away, totally oblivious. Turkeys running if you stand up ever so briefly? yeah right, again I have walked up on these critters IRL and they DO NOT CARE. Everything runs away at the first sign of trouble, no matter how hard you sneak, descent, and take your time. you have to level by doing missions to become sneakier I guess, which is really annoying because it requires HUNTING to LEVEL and I can't get within 100 YARDS OF ANYTHING WITH EARS. Your best bets are to shell out for a hunting stand and wait FOREVER, or try to flush animals toward your friends so they can pretend it's an arcade shooter and take all the kill credit while you run around like an idiot.

weapons are unrealistic. You mean to tell me if I shot a lion in the liver or eyeball with a slightly too small caliber bullet, it's just gonna maul me? I LEGIT PEPPERED a lion with 223 rounds in the face, and it had plenty of time to sprint around the lake, roar at me, and rip my face off only for my friend to kill it and be bummed it was full of holes.

I bought this hoping it would be the like old cabela's games, I was severely disappointed and refuse to spend a bunch of time grinding and even more money just to reach a base line of playable. If there was a way to get better without dedicated real life amounts of time for hunting, this game might be worthwhile, but currently, it's a grind and cash grab more than a hunting game. Very little zen to be had, all the frustrations of hunting are there perfectly though I guess...

Let's get this on the top: I play on Linux and this game works well

Never kinda understood why some one would want a hunting sim. Saw this one on big sale and thought: "Oh what the heck. I'll give it a shot." So, now I have all the dlc and almost 700h of playtime...

The maps are nice and varied, and some places are down right beautiful. Some issues here and there, but it's the common stuff most mainly procedurally generated maps have. The soundscape.... Oh man the soundscape. It's spot on. I don't even care to guess how much of my life I've spent in the great outdoors, but that's the good stuff. After the map (Revontuli Coast) based on Finland (where I live) came out, I noticed that in many places the surroundings were pretty perfect, but in others things were.... wrong. Like an island bordering the open sea had the long smooth rocky side towards the mainland, and the side with trees coming almost to the waterline towards the horizon. It was the wrong way around. I've talked with others from places the maps are based on, and they have similar experiences.

Shooting's pretty decent. You have bullet drop and drag, and wind affects the trajectories in a reasonable manner. A good deal of the organs inside the animals are modelled so that hits in different parts have different effects. Double lungshot and the animal either drops right down, or gets a short distance before the blood loss and shock drops it. Get a flesh wound on a water buffalo, and you can track those blood drops til the end of time. Rifles and pistols have generally two types of ammo, one that does shock and a wide wound channel but loses penetration fast, and a penetration focused that does the opposite. Both tend to have their uses. Bows and x-bows have different draw strengths, that combined with the weight of the arrows or bolts affect the shot. Shotguns come in different gauges (10, 12, 16 and 20) and bird-, and buckshots and slugs.

I think the gamification of hunting is quite decently done. You have those slow times when it feels nothing happens, and then ones where you get a lot of game. Still, you get stuff done at a comfortable rate without much of a hassle. Portable hunting structures (various blinds mostly) and tents etc give some variation and utility. Lures (sound and scent), wind, ambient sound level, terrain and vegetation all play into the sneaking part, as well as the senses of the particular animals around. The story missions are mainly for easy cash and xp for those starting out, and give some ambience. Do them or don't. Nothing's forced.

I think that's the main gist of it. I find Hunter: CotW really relaxing and a good way to get that light nature "fix" if I can't get the real thing. ;)

theHunter: Call of the Wild

Verdict: The landscapes and wildlife are okay. However, the content is poor in essential gameplay areas. The rigid, heavily stalled unlock system, which is modeled on annoying purchase processes, initially prevents the player from experiencing this quickly. Then, however, it turns out that the game lacks the flexibility, depth of play and attention to detail in weapons, animation and player character that would guarantee actual game satisfaction. The lack of bugfixing for years, so to speak, also contributes very negatively to the game's overall image.

Note: This game is unfortunately not just about hunting and nature and having fun. This game is also about conditioning economic processes and worldly attitudes (making money and spending money). It is about promoting an atmosphere of prosperity, globalization and consumption. The missions are on the level of school field trips for 12 year olds. This gives the game an annoying, cautionary aura. This is the main reason for not recommending it.

----------------------------

Fazit: Die Landschaften und die Tierwelt des Spiels sind in Ordnung. Die Inhalte sind jedoch in wesentlichen Spielbereichen dürftig. Das starre, stark hinhaltende, an nervigen Kaufprozessen angelehnte Freischaltsystem verhindert zunächst, dass der Spieler dies schnell erfährt. Dann stellt sich jedoch heraus, dass es dem Spiel an der Flexibilität, Spieltiefe und an Detailtreue bei Waffen, Animation und Spielerfigur fehlt, die tatsächliche  Spielzufriedenheit garantieren würden. Auch das quasi seit Jahren fehlendes Bugfixing trägt sehr negativ zum Gesamtbild des Spieles bei.

Anmerkung: In diesem Spiel geht es leider nicht nur um Jagd und Natur und den Spaß an der Sache. In diesem Spiel geht es auch darum wirtschaftliche Abläufe und weltanschauliche Haltungen zu konditionieren (Geld zu verdienen und Geld auszugeben). Es geht darum eine Atmosphäre der Prosperität, Globalisierung und des Konsums zu fördern. Die Missionen bewegen sich auf dem Niveau von Schulausflügen für 12 Jährige. Dadurch erhält das Spiel eine nervende, belehrende Aura. Dies ist der Hauptgrund der nicht Empfehlung.

Its a very good game but like every other game it has its issues: you kind of have to buy some DLC for the game to be played or if want to have progress, because of the prices of items in the base game. It also seems to have quite a bit of trouble with the cloud sync... it is so easy to lose all your progress and restart right from the beginning if you try to play from another device or something similar, as this has happened to me twice. But still a very good game overall, I would consider a few weapon packs and the ATV upon buying the game though (maybe also the wild goose chase pack, as goose hunting can be a very easy money).
Overall a pretty accurate guide on how to destroy an entire ecosystem with a single rifle (and maybe some duck decoys)

Update (negatives) PSA: The developers downgrade graphic options on the PC for console players' sake. 

On top of this they apparently released an update that made animals spook at an even closer distance. For most players who are fine with crouch walking for 5 hours a day, this is just an additional challenge. The realism is fine, but at some point it gets ridiculous. I've seen countless animals spook at 400m while sitting still.

The game is beautiful and it can be enjoyable, but as you learn it you realize that the mechanics are designed so that you must "herd manage" which involves many many hours of culling animals you don't want in a very complex way that even the experts don't fully understand just to spawn a rare.

It's also a bit of a disappointment that one feature of the game such as tree stands/blinds isn't really a usable feature, meaning you're never going to be able to just sit in one and possibly get lucky with a rare walking by even if you are there during proper feed times or in the correct need zone. Tents are spawn points and stands/blinds are for example only there to reduce the amount of suppression you get for a kill. Not for sitting in one spot and waiting.

The Big thing I love about this game is how random it is..every time I log in to play something new happens...the randomness of the animals wandering around the maps always leads to some of the most unexpected and memorable things that have ever occurred to me in any game I've played over the many years of playing games...I have about 1,000 hours of game play with it and it never has felt old or boring...a real gem of a game...

4. That is the number that represents how many times this game has refused to close and causing me to have to force my PC to shut down. Then when I log back into the game, I've lost nearly an entire days worth of progress. Most recently 3 levels of progression, nearly all of the rest of my missions in hirsch and the full map discovery of Fernando. My desire to play the game is dropping massively because of this. It is extremely deflating to play a game for a whole day and then it doesn't save properly or the game doesn't close right and you lose the entire days worth of progress. Honestly, I don't know if I'd actually recommend the game to others.


Edit: Thanks to literally NO ONE WHATSOEVER... I've found the fix. You need to turn off the cloud save if you are having this issue. Additionally you need to close the game via the main menu rather than ALT+F4 or exiting to desktop. Apart from that the game is perfectly fine and enjoyable.

Edit 2023: New issues galore! Cant play for more that 30 minutes without the game crashing. Been sending reports with request for the devs to email me with more information... been three weeks and NOT A SINGLE EMAIL. There is no crash report with real information in it. there is no error message or crash number. There are literally zero indication as to what could even possibly be causing the crashes so that i can attempt to fix the problem. Ive tried to implement a number of fixes but none have worked. It sure would be fantastic if I could get ANY help whatsoever for this from literally ANYONE working on the game.

If you are looking for a game to test your hunting skills, this is the game for you. I love the design and the quality the developers and testers put into making this game. As a Hunter in real life, I cannot recommend this game enough. I actually use this game to help me prepare for hunting season by making sure I make good shot placement in the game, so that way I can do the same in real life. If you are new to the world of hunting in game or in real life, Patience is key. There are multiple ways to play this game whether that be by calling animals or stalking them. All of the DLC for this game is fantastic. It's great to see a gaming company actually listen to their audience for once. I have nothing but praise for this game, but the only thing negative I have to say Is I wish the studio would add a Bundle that includes all of the DLC for this game, so that way newcomers can get the best experience possible, for one price. I hope I have helped you decide whether or not this amazing game is for you or not. I hope you enjoy your experience and join this wonderful community, Welcome to the Call of The WIld.

I watched Rooster on Youtube and absolutely fell in love with the game. The experience I have had playing and learning has resulted in me obtaining my own bow and embarking on a bow only hunting adventure in my local zones. 

The game is beautiful with its scenery and variants of animals and sizes. From the shot placements, to the equipment, this game delivers a wonderful experience of both visual and audio that engage the audience and enhance your experience through well planned missions. The variety of maps, creatures, and equipment, all provide an overall sensation of a proper hunt. The different elements of wolves attacking to snow covering the surrounding region is honestly breathtaking.

I may have only 50ish hours in the game but I can feel there are plenty more to come with my trophy hunting and lodge setups. Thank you developers for making such a fantastic game and I love this game!

I have 300+ hours on this game on my xbox. The game itself, (hunting, weapons, the map, etc) is great. Stealth is well developed, animals act well, and it's fun to play. If you see reviews claiming the game is "boring" because they couldn't find any animals after running around for 30 minutes it's because they were playing it wrong. This game REQUIRES patience, so if that's in short supply, look elsewhere. Granted, if you just want to run around and shoot animals, this game is extremely boring, however if you enjoy taking things slowly, trying to place a perfect shot, following animals, etc, this game is great. The game was originally released unfinished. Nowadays it's pretty stable and the graphics look great if you can play on high settings. However, what makes this review negative, and many other reviews too, is that DLC spam is insane. 100+ dollars worth of dlc? It's fucked. Half of the DLC are things that SHOULD be in the PAYED GAME. Half the maps, over 40 guns, night optics, many species, lodges, tents??? One of the things that specifically aggravates me are the quads. Sure, they're not that expensive, around 4 dollars, but 4 dollars for something that 100% should and needs to be in the non-dlc game? The maps are huge and when I played on xbox and didn't have dlc it took literal hours to unlock all the lodges and vantage points. They're not needed but if you don't find them you're kinda just fucked. Truly, how much DLC does one game need? This is EA levels of little goblin cashgrabs. I can't recommend buying this game simply because the publishers don't deserve any more money.

I bought this to wander idly through lush and verdant landscapes, which was a mistake as it’s a hunting simulator. Every five minutes a bloodthirsty German noble calls me and directs me to murder and “harvest” wildlife like I’m in some horrible horror movie. Really harshes my buzz. 

As a hunting simulator, it’s pretty great, I guess? Animal behaviour is complex, wind and scent and sound are richly simulated, bullet travel matters. 

I think it’s great that a game finally acknowledges headshots aren’t everything. If only a few more FPSs would follow suit.

Anyway, if you like hunting, this is probably great. If you don’t like hunting and just want a beautiful hiking simulator, maybe look elsewhere.

I wish steam had a neutral option. This is a reasonably good game at what I consider to be a reasonable price, however it is just not something I can find enjoyable. I played this game for a short time and then watched my gf try to get a bunch of achievements, but anyone claiming that it is only an issue of patience is not thinking straight.

The game is very realistic in many aspects, including that hunting is incredibly slow and includes a lot of sitting still, but it is also very 'gamey' in other aspects, such as starting you out with garbage equipment so that there can be a progression system, giving animals super powers (real animals would be constantly fleeing if they were somehow able to recognize a twig snapping 500m away as a threat, and I don't think tanking a shotgun blast to the head and running several kilometres away is possible either) and sacrificing basic touches like an animation for a door opening in order to pump out more maps.

The bugginess is moderate-low, animals sometimes teleport and shot paths are not accurate somewhat often, but nothing super game breaking. No crashes if I remember right.

Some other reviews mention DLC spam, this is correct. The DLC quad bike is absolutely required for the base game, you are forced to trek across massive maps, which look largely the same across the area, with a character who seems to have broken legs (I know he/she's carrying a lot of equipment, but it still feels bad). The base game and quad bike are both not too expensive, but making something so important into a DLC is just bad on principle.

Completionists beware, you will probably suffer an aneurysm before getting 100% achievements.

I want to give this game an amazing review - there are a lot of really great things about this game. The Achilles heel appears to be stat tracking and server management. I've killed the Valuez Werecoyote 3 times now. Still have the mission...does not show in my hunter log. The Angler is also experiencing the same issue, and is not worth playing currently.

Another note is the guns for level 2 and 3 animals (even after the 22-250 and *supposedly* buffed .223). There is no penetration on these rounds at all. I've lost countless grades due to a round that should have 100% reached vitals but fell short, its nonsense. It's almost like these folks have never put their hands on a firearm...

The Developers need to hire people who know how to deal with these problems, because they are infuriating to play right now. 

I hope they figure it out to make these games worth playing - is the nicest thing I can say right now.

Also, discussions need to be re-opened. Its not cool, nor should it be 'OK'  to block us out here. 
*this was my B, I guess I didn't realize how discussions worked. it seemed like I had to have some kind of status to start a topic/thread*

**Update: The server issues have been resolved, and changed my recommendation to YES because of that alone. I've also received a response from a Dev that they will look into the penetration for level 2 and 3 firearms. I hope they just change them to work in the same respective way that a level 4-8 works on it's intended targets. Consistency... there we go. <3 **

Pumping 10 shots of 45. into a wild boar or a deer at close range and the thing still running off several kilometers, is just complete nonsense, especially if you hit the lung various times.

I realized I never wrote a review of this game despite the number of hours I have played. This is the first hunting game I've ever played and I've been enjoying it a lot, even with the annoying bugs that are not getting fixed as quickly as they should be. I like doing the missions as they challenge me to do things I maybe otherwise wouldn't be keen on trying. Unfortunately, many missions are bugged as are some achievements. There are other issues in the game as well, but I just tend to avoid things that I have noticed causing problems. Not the optimal solution, but I play this to relax, so I try not to be bothered.

I don't generally like shooting games, because I lack the quick reflexes they require, but this is as slow paced as you want it to be. Quick reflexes are rarely needed, and even if you're slow and do get trampled by a buffalo, you just get transported back to the nearest outpost, so it is an annoyance at the most.

I have bought all of the reserves so far, and some of them are more interesting than others, but I don't regret getting them. I have a bunch of other DLCs as well, like the ATV, tents, stands, and several gun packs. You can play the game with just the base game, but the DLCs definitely make it better. Just do your research to determine, which ones you want, and wait for a sale.

And I've never got motion sickness while playing this game, although I'm very prone to it.

This game has some issues, but the devs constantly work on it and solve a lot of these issues.  In game animal populations are high, and the game does not tell you where all the animals are.  You can literally hunt as long or as short as you want.  The initial grind is a bit heavy, but theres a lot of open hunting.  Shoot what you want when you want.  Definitely not a COD type shoot em up, if you run through the map you wont see anything.

Pros:
Completely open world, beautiful graphics
Somewhat realistic physics, bullets have definite properties.  dont try shooting a moose with your default gun.
everything purchased with in game credits
shoot what you want when you want
no licenses
update - now has small game hunting, defintely worth purchasing
Some animals will actively hunt you on some of the new maps, which is a refreshing changeup

Cons:
A little too grindy.  have to shoot pretty much everything you see in the beginning.
animals still get stuck in random spots, though this has been greatly improved.


Overall the best hunting game ive ever played.  Definitely worth the purchase.

Review update:
The major issues from the past are gone, and there are ways with the DLC to pretty much turn the game into a shooting gallery as well.  Which is actually necessary if you ever wish to harvest a super rare or a great one.  The new Te Arowa And Austrailia reserves are phenomenal.  Lots of open terrain so you can see stuff for hundreds of yards away.

Def a must buy if you like any sort of hunting game.
